Madam President, it seems to me that it is somewhat symptomatic for us, that is, for the EU in general, but also for this Parliament in particular, that we automatically engage in discussions about situations in countries whose circumstances are, in fact, not new.
It is unfortunately the case that all too often overnight events cause us to suddenly and in waves find ourselves making political demands that I sometimes find rather questionable.
I believe it does not behoove us to allow a failed airplane attack to trigger a general debate about Yemen alone.
I believe we should be clear that it would behoove us to devise a strategy for addressing this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a close analysis, specifically that it is a failed state where a government operates that no longer has control over large parts of the country. We should analyze for ourselves what risks arise for Europe from this situation.
The risks appear to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging off the coast of Yemen, where piracy is apparently taking place.
Therefore, I believe it is up to us, and perhaps also to Ms. Eschten, to consider what we can do against these risks.
In my view, the primary answer is how can we support the government in Yemen to regain control of the country and mitigate these risks.

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country, of course, also need to be held. But I do not believe that it is truly meaningful or that we will be taken seriously if we now initiate a list of demands across all policy issues, ranging from media freedom to the rights of women here in Parliament.
I believe this will not lead to a solution in Yemen. Instead, we should focus on what specific help we can provide in the current situation to address the acute problem. Thank you.

Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, the massacre on November 23rd of last year in the province of Maguindanao in the Philippines was a dark day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
57 dead, raped women, injured. They speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, it is particularly striking to me that 30 journalists were among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, in no documented case have more journalists ever been murdered at once.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to use clear language, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, as the EPP, we call for the text as presented to be softened at three points through separate voting. For we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence, and therefore refrain from making accusatory remarks about the government.
Therefore, on behalf of the EPP, I request a separate vote on Recital F in particular. It accuses the Philippines of exhibiting all the signs of a malfunctioning legal system.
In point 2, we would like to eliminate the assumption of so-called initial delays in the clarification process.
Finally, Point 6 claims that there are missing persons who are imprisoned in Philippine jails.
Even this is currently an unproven assumption and, in our opinion, should be removed. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, first of all, I would like to extend my sincere thanks to Mr Leichtfried for an excellent report that carries forward viable and valuable content.
What is the ultimate goal?
The focus is on enhancing transparency, consumer protection, safety and coordination, as well as quality management.
I must caution against creating a new authority to address these issues.
I view the principle of subsidiarity in the report as positive. It should certainly be retained.
For me, a clear distinction between taxes and fees is also essential, as well as all tasks that are sovereign in nature, whether they involve identification services or not.
From a police perspective, whether it be for counter-terrorism or similar measures, all these actions must be clearly funded from tax revenue, not user fees.
If individual nation-states then have a vital interest in taking additional security measures beyond this, I also see them as being responsible for the costs in this area.
Those who commission security in the sovereign domain also pay for it.
Certainly, I see it differently in the technical or personal sphere, which may undoubtedly be to the detriment of the passenger, provided it is clearly declared what is at stake.
Notably, however, the impact assessment presented by the Commission calculates the cost of these measures at approximately 0.1 percent of the total transport fee.
We should therefore not start too high.
I believe that we can reach a viable compromise even with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has significant concerns regarding subsidiarity in this area.
I hope that the final result is very close to our proposal. Thank you.

Policy coherence in the interest of development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

It makes little sense, for example, to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries while at the same time destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.

Similarly, we can advocate for better healthcare to our heart's content, but if we hinder the trade of generic drugs or drive medication prices to unaffordable heights through patent extensions, our efforts will be in vain.

And agrofuels may slightly reduce CO2 emissions in the EU, but they lead to deforestation and land-use change in developing countries, thereby causing more climate change, which we were precisely trying to avoid. Not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and arable land for food production.
At present, we, that is, the EU as a whole, are not particularly coherent.
The EU has recognized in theory for some time that policy measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty enshrines policy coherence in the interest of development.
Article 208 states that, when implementing political measures that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take into account the objectives of development cooperation.
We must be measured against this demand.
This year, we are reviewing the progress made towards achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear that without policy coherence, we will not be able to keep our promises.

We must be aware of this responsibility, as all those who enact and implement laws. Before deciding on a measure, there must be an impact assessment to enable us to identify potential negative effects of European legislation on developing countries.
We need expertise within the Council, Commission, and Parliament that identifies inconsistencies.
The Commission's work program on policy coherence is a good step in this direction.
And now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence in the interest of development means that in the fisheries reform, we must take greater account of the interests of the people on the ground and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing corporations.
It means that we need to dry up tax havens into which funds from developing countries are flowing.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if the suspicion remains that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that, in establishing the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the competencies of the Development Commissioner should be expanded, not restricted.
It also involves, for instance, enabling Fairtrade in the awarding of contracts in municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rühle has proposed.
In many cases, we need to keep a close eye on members of the Commission and the Council to ensure they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us, the representatives, to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to improve networking among the committees, and we require a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee adopted unanimously, makes many good proposals and brings us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.

Madam President, dear colleagues, for months we have been discussing the issue of driving and working hours in road transport.
And I find myself wondering what arguments are now being marshaled to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is sheer nonsense.
The latest argument is that one must urgently do something here so that nothing changes.
Don't you notice, dear Ms. Bauer, how absurd this line of argument has become, how permeated it is with lies and half-truths?
This debate is about nothing other than an extension of working hours for the self-employed.
In labor law, however, the principle has been for 150 years to protect people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and employed workers.
It is entirely irrelevant whether it is a self-employed individual who is overworked or whether an employer overworks an employed driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, partly also from employers and clients.
Secondly. With regard to road traffic safety, it is claimed here that nothing could possibly happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a hardware store for hobbyists, and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws with the attitude of "let's see what comes out of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are designed to be hazardous, especially in road traffic with major consequences.
Third point. Who, exactly, is supposed to enforce such a nuanced regulation, as you envision it, on our roads in the future?
Today, a regional labor judge cannot determine whether someone appears to be self-employed or an independent contractor without an extensive review of the case files.
Abandon this nonsense; it's about fair competition.
It is not about setting a priority today, tomorrow, for the future debate on extending working hours.
Do not play such games with this house. I thank you.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Today, as I have for many years, I advocate for road traffic safety, improved working conditions for our professional drivers, and the enhancement of their occupational profile.

Undoubtedly, today's focus is not on the traffic safety regulations concerning driving and rest periods, which all professional drivers, whether self-employed or employed, must adhere to. Today, we are concerned with work time regulations.
It is primarily an employee protection measure, serving solely to provide social protection for drivers and in no way relating to road safety.
We do not need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Adherence to working hours for self-employed truck and bus drivers cannot be monitored without significant bureaucratic effort, nor is there a compelling reason why such monitoring should be carried out in the first place.

Restricting the permissible working hours of self-employed professional drivers, and potentially also self-employed craftsmen, architects, or members of parliament in this way, sends the wrong signal.
Rather, member states should ensure that false self-employment is addressed among

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, just a few days ago, we were shocked to see on television footage how vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries were flooded by water.
People have lost their lives in the floods, and our deepest sympathies go out to their loved ones. Villages, towns, agricultural land, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images. However, the immense damage must still be painstakingly eliminated.
In addressing damages of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
In the wake of the flood disaster of 1997, Poland and this time other Central European countries are once again affected by a major flood catastrophe.
We cannot yet control the weather, and floods are part of the natural behavior of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we must ask are whether, in awareness of the fact that these natural events can always occur, the right measures are in place to prevent such tragedies.
Damages from such natural events were incurred and whether, for example, in landscape planning, the issues of sustainable disaster protection were given due consideration.
If aid is granted, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster to secure their livelihoods.

Then, however, more should be done at the European level to prevent damage caused by natural disasters, with member states coordinating their efforts in international cooperation, as natural catastrophes do not stop at national borders.

The fact that jointly implemented preventive measures can provide protection is demonstrated by the flood protection measures on the Oder River, which have been jointly established there by Polish and German authorities to date.
But we are far from the end yet.
We do not need a European disaster protection agency,
The protection of its country from disasters should be the primary task of a government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

However, the coordination of assistance in the event of damage or incidents should also be subject to efficient European coordination. And the organizations that provide rapid and unbureaucratic aid on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear their expenses.
Therefore, I support the Commissioner's plans, Ms. Georgieva, to swiftly implement these measures...
