Thank you, Mr Zeller, one and a half minutes. Thank you, Mr President. Firstly, I would like to extend my sincere thanks to Mathieu Grosch for this comprehensive report and the immense work he has put into it.

That Europe, without dividing borders and without a functioning transport system, cannot be experienced, and the European economy would not be successful, indeed would not be conceivable, without efficient, future-proof transport systems on land, on water, and in the air.
In particular, for environmentally friendly rail transport, we need more community and less national selfishness.
For a sustainable future of transportation, all modes of transport must address the challenges in society, environmental protection, and the economy.
The report provides valuable and guiding insights on this matter.
I can only disagree with the report on one point. I cannot support the formation of a transport fund from Cohesion Policy funds.
Why?
Certainly, transport is a key driver of cohesion in Europe. However, a dedicated fund from the cohesion policy budget would not meet the expectations it raises.
Unilaterally burden the Cohesion Fund and relieve the Member States, which are particularly affected, of their responsibility to ensure a sustainable future for transport.
And we have just established a special committee in Parliament to debate the future shape of the European Union's Cohesion and Structural Funds. Its work should not be prioritized.
Therefore, I also ask you to approve the amendment to the report.
Moreover, I believe that when we discuss sustainability and the future of transportation systems, magnetic levitation technology should also be given a future and a chance. Thank you.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, while we have a common internal market, we have fragmented supervision.
That this cannot work is obvious.
We need strong, central European structures that utilize the expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states' organs, but also have the authority to intervene in emergencies.
I believe that the citizen, given the immense tax burden imposed by this crisis, expects swift, rapid, and appropriate decisions to be made here.
Citizens care little about power games played at the national level, where the only question is who gets to make the decisions.
What the citizen wants is for decisions to be made effectively, for problems to be solved.

And this is objectively the case that, when it comes to measures in an emergency situation, this needs to be centrally regulated and decided at the European level, if coordination between the member states is insufficient and does not work.
This aligns with the decisions of the G20, the G8, and the heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The wheel makes him small, smaller, smallest check.
This is not an acceptable policy for citizens.
We expect the Council to act. Thank you.

Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, dear colleagues, one does occasionally wonder what we have actually been doing for over a year now in terms of discussions, debates, and numerous meetings in the trilogue, where I could have imagined spending my time in more pleasant ways.

And one stands, at this point in time, more than a year after the European elections, where we still proclaimed on the streets and squares how we wanted to tame the financial markets, essentially before a very meager to non-existent result.
The problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that now operate globally.
And the member states still believe that they are able to enforce rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely the fact that this did not work contributed, while not directly triggering the financial crisis, to its impact on Europe as well.

That is why I ask myself when this insight, which is readily formulated in Sunday speeches, will also be implemented in political action. Suddenly, it is about protecting stock exchanges, about protecting banking structures, and no longer about protecting citizens.

As the European Parliament, we have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also dedicate themselves to it, for they are co-responsible for implementing proper supervisory rules for the benefit of citizens, ensuring that individuals' savings are permanently secure.

And I do, of course, hope, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, that the Commission will now truly do everything possible to ensure that we reach a good outcome as quickly as possible in the interests of the people of Europe.
Dear colleagues, we bear the responsibility, here in the European Parliament, for the implementation of robust regulation of financial markets.
All that we had proposed was significantly watered down in the trialogues.
The council and the government do not want strong intervention powers.
Giegold is right when he referred to what is currently happening as "provincial thinking."
The aim appears to be not strict regulation, but rather designing the system to be slightly more fail-safe.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will be unable to exert effective control over financial markets.
Inadequate consequences are being drawn from this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, thus preparing the next crisis.
Many national economies, including those in Europe, will not withstand the upcoming shocks, with all the social and economic consequences for the people of Europe.
They expect this predator of financial market capitalism to be recaptured and the primacy of politics to be restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated over the weekend, "We need a strong and unified European financial supervisory authority and a common rule for all member states,"
Member states and he advocates for stricter capital rules, then this is an appeal to this Parliament to truly constitute these rules.

It is the responsibility of this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to now urgently implement effective regulation. This would only be the first step towards a return to the status quo ante.
Finally, let actions follow the grandiose promises. My faction stands for strong European regulation.
Everything else, no regulation, would be a danger to the euro, to a common EU, and to democracy. I thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Poor timing for this discussion.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win, even if it was to be the last time in this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because we are no longer allowed to watch and then they will likely not win after all.

But on the subject, Commissioner, yes, you are giving the correct signal. Commissioner, Mr. President, today or tomorrow, to be precise, we are finalizing a legislative package that we have been discussing for over two years.
The blame for this lies not only with the controversy but also with a European election held in between and the entry into force of a new EU Treaty, which necessitated some adjustments on our part.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we should now vote on a compromise that is certainly worth saying yes to, even if one perhaps does so with a clenched fist in one's pocket at one point or another.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One aspect concerns the environmental requirements for industrial facilities.
The aim is to better implement the best available technology in Europe.

I believe that we have found an exceptional clause in the compromise now before us, which, Mr. Botocznik, and this is clearly addressed to you, gives the European Commission the tool it needs to intervene in the following cases:

In the coming years, there should be a stronger and more rigorous focus on ensuring that the approximately 52,000 industrial facilities concerned in Europe ultimately employ the best available technology more effectively than they do currently.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
One thing I would like to address and reflect here as well, because I cannot comprehend it at all.
I have often been told that the use of the best available technology is too expensive and that we are jeopardizing the competitiveness of European industry, especially in times of crisis.
I seldom like to dwell on my past, but I hail from the former GDR, from East Germany.

The economic and ecological collapse of East Germany (GDR) can also be attributed to the fact that, over several decades, investment in technological advancements was neglected during the final years.

And I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, by virtue of its existence, is called upon to invest in the latest state of the art, because otherwise it will lose its competitiveness and, of course, incidentally reduce emissions of pollutants.
I believe we have the opportunity today to enact a law that improves this initial situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is the clenched fist I mentioned, are the large combustion plants.

Once again, as we have already done in the last directive, we are discussing further exceptions until the year 2020, in some cases 2023, for large combustion plants that do not have to meet the environmental requirements, in particular the air pollutant limit values.
I direct this address to the Council, but perhaps also a little to all of us, that we really need to consider carefully whether it makes sense for us to regularly
We welcome ambitious environmental objectives, which we also discuss and endorse. But whenever it comes to implementing them, to enacting concrete legislation, a tragedy begins to unfold in Europe.
Then the member states suddenly realize what it costs, which bills they have to pay, and usually those who have made advance payments are also penalized.
There is indeed a number of Member States that already meet the requirements today and will ultimately be left out in the rain.
And I'll say it again here, both in industrial plants and in large-scale combustion facilities, they are essentially coal-fired power plants. Let's not talk about science fiction.
We do not discuss things that are not available, but rather the state-of-the-art.
Best Available Techniques, which are competitive and cost-effective in the market, can be integrated into these facilities. And against this backdrop, we conclude today.
today a package of laws that I believe is better than what is currently in force. Therefore, I encourage us all to support it.

And I would also like to thank the colleagues who have worked together over the past two years, sometimes with great tenacity, for their support, their contributions, and above all, for the fact that almost all the important factions have co-signed this compromise. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Three things have happened while we were debating. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become the football world champion.
A good omen, I believe.
We will see who exactly it will be.
I do not want to express any preferences right now.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, many thanks. Doesn't happen every day.
It is worth bearing that in mind.
And thirdly, the world is still in order; even among the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
For unfortunately, our colleague Bas Aykut has already left again.
But heartfelt congratulations, of course, to our Dutch friends.
I would like to contribute two aspects to the debate that is about to follow.
Firstly, I understand all the concerns and difficulties of my Eastern European friends only too well.
As an East German, I am also half an East European.
And I understand that not every environmental policy step taken in Western European countries over the past few decades can be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe now.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that is correct.
But I believe that even taking this sentence into account, it is worth agreeing to this compromise, as it does justice to the different starting positions in which many member states find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best available techniques endangers competitiveness, especially vis-à-vis China. This argument is not only wrong, it is actually dangerous.
We must come to terms with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are undoubtedly cheaper than in our region.
And we will only succeed in this competition if we employ the best available technology across all industries.
Those who do not do this lose competitiveness.
No one, not even this law, demands that an industrial facility be shut down tomorrow.
No one expects a jump from 0 to 100 to achieve any pollutant limit within a week.
We have sufficient transition periods. But to say that one should forego this for competitive reasons is incorrect.

And I believe that with this directive, we have not only made a decision with regard to environmental policy, but also in terms of industrial policy. It will be worth working on in the coming years. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin by expressing my gratitude to the colleagues from the other groups for their contribution to the creation of my report on Kosovo, and also to Ms. Eva Mahr, who has done invaluable work in the secretariat.

And to you, Commissioner, I would also like to express my thanks for the good cooperation, but also for what you mentioned, that it was important to you to travel to the north of Kosovo as well, to even spend a night there, and thus make it clear to the population that you also stand up for them.
You gave a speech at the university and inaugurated the EU House there.

I believe this was an important signal to make clear what this European Parliament has expressed in the past and again now, namely its support for an independent Kosovo on its path towards the European Union.
We currently find ourselves at a crucial juncture for Kosovo, one that is particularly significant for the citizens of all ethnic groups within Kosovo.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will decide and issue its opinion on the status of the declaration of independence made just over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion, will then provide an opportunity, a kind of open window, as they say in English, to put regional cooperation on a new footing, but based on the principle of state sovereignty.

starting with Kosovo and its independence. And to make it clear that the common future for all states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo, and for all others lies in membership of the European Union, and that the problems that still exist must be resolved on the path towards this goal.
It is also the text of the resolution of one that makes it clear: the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am glad that we have a majority in favor of this, which also urges the five member states that have not yet recognized to do so soon. It also calls on the Commission once again to initiate visa liberalization as soon as possible.

for the citizens of the country, especially the young people, must not be left with the impression that they live in an isolated state, unable to venture beyond its borders, while all those around them are soon to embrace this future.
I believe that is the assignment.
I hope to find a large majority in support of this in tomorrow's plenary session as well.

I have also tabled a new amendment that expresses deep regret over the outbreaks of violence in recent days, strongly hopes for swift and independent clarification, and does not use this as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks. Thank you.
Madam President, esteemed representative, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, the most recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the

The burning down of houses and the flows of tens of thousands of refugees, who were leaving their hometowns and trying to flee the violence, all of this shocked me and evoked compassion for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan once again cast a spotlight on the situation in Central Asia, which cannot leave us in the European Parliament indifferent.
On the contrary, we should direct our entire attention to the countries in this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on the states that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but rather consider all states on an equal footing within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
I believe that is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which only two decades ago freed themselves from the once tsarist and later Soviet rule, bear a heavy legacy.
Arbitrary borders drawn by Stalin without regard for the ancestral homelands of the peoples living there apparently hinder coexistence within and beyond the borders of these states.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions such as in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, where hundreds of thousands...

Labor immigration, when forced and allowed to escalate into conflict resolution through the use of violence as we are currently witnessing in Kyrgyzstan, casts a shadow of uncertainty over these countries' future trajectory.
Here, the European Union must not merely watch on, but act.

If we do not want to allow these states' paths to lead into fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to leave the people there exposed to dictatorial regimes indefinitely, our full commitment is required.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we require engagement with these states, active support for the democratic forces emerging there.

Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance in her efforts to bring peace to Kyrgyzstan and to establish stable political conditions. Let us engage in the debate on this matter and proceed to the vote tomorrow.

Resolution must also be followed by action, so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we are not leaving them alone on their path to the future or handing them over to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high. We should not disappoint them. Thank you.
The report is accurate for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the subtleties of which will cause us great concern.
The second point is that the European ambassador will henceforth manage Commission funds.
This exposes the funds to a variety of risks, and the collateral for these risks is still completely unclear at this point.
The third point concerns the relinquishing of this Parliament's rights in a Council regulation.
In this process, we are effectively co-deciding, yet we have allowed the Council regulation to preempt parliamentary rights.
Therefore, for my dossier, the budget regulations, I would like to state that I do not consider myself bound by today's decisions.
The fourth point concerns the question of how we actually interact with each other in Parliament.
In the last session, we passed a parliamentary reform and procedures that we have all now trampled underfoot, with the approval of the presidency and also with the consent of the president.
Why are we enacting a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures when, in crucial moments, we already violate them and do not comply?
For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Commissioner, I am very much in favor of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
That is completely incomparable.
Cloning is animal cruelty. And many colleagues have already stated this here,
I also presented this before the summer break in the discussion we had. Only a fraction of animal clones are actually viable.
And those who survive, many of them die very, very young, and in a most agonizing manner.
They suffer from malformations of extremities, of organs.
They have immune deficiencies; they are susceptible to illness.
This means pain and suffering, and precisely this agonizing death.
Can we really take responsibility for that?
We advocate so strongly for animal welfare and then we want to support such a technique.
No, we do not want that, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is also only consistent.

Yes, we are aware that products derived from cloned animals or their offspring are likely not harmful to health, and I personally believe they would indeed be suitable for human consumption. However, there is in fact no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why then should we engage in this cloning?
It is entirely unnecessary to engage in this animal cruelty. And the population simply does not want it either.
The population does not want these products. We do not need them either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
And therefore, we aim to establish a clear and explicit regulation specifically for cloned animals and, yes, also for their offspring.
I advocate for a ban on cloning and cloned products within the European Union. Moreover, I believe we can enforce this.
Of course, this must also apply to imports.
And I want to be certain that cloned meat is not secretly slipped into my food without proper labeling, as has already happened here in Germany.
And I do not believe that all meat can be traced back to its origin.
It may be possible with beef.
But with pork, due to the volume produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether there was actually a clone in the ancestry.
Fundamentally, I think yes, it is a principle-based question, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have stated that we must also address ethical questions and we are responsible for ethical matters as well.
And then, of course, there is the question of animal welfare, but it is also a different matter.
Experience shows that, as a livestock producer who has studied this field, all reproduction techniques, once they have proven effective in animal production, are ultimately applied to humans as well.
So we must ask ourselves today: Do we want and are we able to accept cloning technology in the not-too-distant future, even for humans?
So I don't want to and I also can't.
And even if a clone of me might be able to donate a vital organ to me in the future, a clone of myself, I would not want that.
And I do not believe that this is an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that it would not be at all fair in the future if we were to allow cloning.
And that is why we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring across the entire EU.
And I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can enforce this.
We do not have to imitate everything the U.S. shows us, despite all transatlantic friendship. Thank you.
Warmest thanks, colleagues. It is no coincidence that we cannot easily reach an agreement here in this case, as two incompatible matters are being conflated.
We likely could have reached a good agreement on trademark protection if we had focused on that.
But the conflation with the matter of the internet is also factually incorrect, because new and different strategies are required here than in material law.
This cannot be simply transferred.
Furthermore, one must be aware that we pay for every criminal prosecution on the internet with infringements on civil rights, because one cannot see or find this out on their own.
And the third point is truly clear to me. If I already equate the enjoyment of culture on the web with the threat of punishment, so that I practically always have one foot in the
If I view the internet as a prison, then I will not be able to take advantage of the opportunities it offers for art, culture, and creativity.
That is why my appeal is to keep talking about it. That would be clear.
Many thanks.
Mr. Chairman, property, whether intellectual or physical, is a cornerstone of the market economy.
And therefore, I believe it is important that we consider how we can address this issue together in a sound consensus.
In all cases, we need a warning signal.
One-Stop-Shop. It needs to become easier for consumers, the self-employed, and small and medium-sized businesses to obtain corresponding licenses here.
And it is the availability of licenses for intellectual property rights that are valid throughout the EU that is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
We need above all the original language, so that it is available across Europe as a whole.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible for licenses granted for a language to be valid throughout Europe, thereby enabling all citizens to use them.
We require interoperability and technical neutrality to be able to utilize this intellectual property accordingly.
And we above all need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Dear colleagues, I have noted that the Council does not wish to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council here that the European Parliament already wishes to discuss this matter, and that the Council cannot behave like a kindergarten and simply refuse to answer our questions or engage with our proposals.
Secondly, I must ask the Council in this context whether it now wants Lisbon or whether it does not want Lisbon.
Lisbon is not merely a technical amendment; it entails more tasks, more task fulfillment, and thus also addressing related financial questions.
In addition, the Council has adopted decisions that result in new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the Council wishes this and if the Council wants to ensure that no more money is spent, then the Council must also specify exactly where it wants to make savings, how it wants to save, and where it wants to reallocate funds precisely, rather than just providing general statements.

suggest percentage shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where the inconveniences should be allocated, especially given that our options for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited.

The tasks they additionally assigned to us, however, are so challenging that they do not involve minor, trivial amounts, but I will mention only the areas of the financial solidarity of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
And if the program needs to be utilized, it involves significant amounts that cannot be casually shuffled around.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to issues of internal security, the same applies to major research questions, and the same applies to topics when I turn to the Parliament's priority areas, namely youth education and research.
We are dealing with partial lack of implementation. We are also partly confronted with a lack of transparency in the allocation of funds.
All these questions must be addressed and dealt with concretely among each other, rather than being answered by the Council's silence.
Dear Commissioner Hahn, colleagues, I have an issue with parts of the debate.
When we talk about mountains, islands, and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from some contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that's not how it is.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which are sovereign.
And the implementation of European decisions and objectives, according to the principle of subsidiarity, remains the responsibility of the member states.

When considering the European level, we have always paid particular attention to these areas—mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, and islands. This is reflected in the Commission's communications up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in the Parliament, too, many resolutions have been adopted to support this region.

When I hear many complaints here now that there are still deficiencies in these areas, the question arises for me: how have the member states dealt with the impulses we have sent from the European level? How have they responded to them?
And how have the regions themselves approached this and utilized the European funding opportunities?

A new strategy is being demanded here. I do feel sorry for the officials at DG Regio who are expected to encapsulate the myriad problems of islands, mountainous regions, and sparsely populated areas into a single strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies—Danube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change, and so on—to the extent that we will soon need a strategy for strategies in order to maintain an overview.

Dear colleagues, enough of the jesting. I believe the crucial point, which was also mentioned today, and for which I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for bringing it up, is that we must fight to ensure that there is also a cohesion policy and a regional policy at European level after 2013.
That, I believe, is the focal point of our work, and we should also convince our colleagues in Parliament that this will be the case.
And in a continuation of coalition and regional policies beyond 2013, mountains, islands, and the other regions will also find their place.
We should not, however, get sidetracked with individual resolutions on this topic for which there is currently no cause. Thank you.

Mr. President, dear colleagues,

First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the colleagues who have worked so intensively on this project, especially to my colleague Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European politics is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that provide ongoing assistance.
We have experienced these supply security situations on multiple occasions.
The issue of supply security has thus become clearer and more pronounced.
We were compelled to act, and we did act.

We have found solutions that were not simple, solutions that also mean new instruments, and what I find interesting about them is that they do not merely establish infrastructure standards in Europe, do not only create common rules for prevention and emergency plans, do not only provide certainty, as the Commissioner correctly stated.
has demonstrated not only that we can offer people 30 days of security in the future, but also that we are able to explore compromises. Compromises that then lead to actionable solutions. This was

along the way, but it is now becoming apparent that both the role and responsibility of the companies that build the networks are at the forefront, as are the networks themselves, but also the flexibility of policy, which states that we will not force things that ultimately prove unprofitable and unwise.

are no longer reasonable. For example, flexibility in terms of outflows, necessary outflows, but not at any price and at all times, rather also the necessity or possibility of being able to assess individual cases, as well as strengthening cooperation at the regional level.

Equally important, I believe, is the emphasis that Member States must also fulfill their responsibilities. But if solutions cannot be found there, then the Commission receives an additional task. The Commission, which is strengthened, but does not decide alone, rather decides when other solutions are no longer possible or has the final say.
So flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, but last but not least ensure that there are solutions. And that is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, and esteemed Commissioners, I need not emphasize the importance of coalition and regional policy for coexistence and integration in Europe.
I also believe that future regional and cohesion policy must pay increased attention to cities.
For cities are an important engine in the development of Europe.
At the same time, however, you are currently experiencing ecological, economic, and social problems to a particularly great extent.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn. What options do you see to emphasize the urban dimensions?
Specifically, Commissioner, you recently hinted at an event held here that you could envision a specific percentage of regional funds being set aside, precisely to emphasize the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
If so, what percentage could this be, if applicable?

Thank you, Mr. Chair. Firstly, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for initiating a new debate here as a former Minister for Economic Affairs and Innovation, which, I believe, can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe were to create one additional job, we would no longer have unemployment in Europe.
We should therefore consider how we can specifically enable small and medium-sized enterprises to take on new employees and, accordingly, become actively involved in international export markets.
But the research infrastructure is also an important concern, just as the infrastructure in the transportation sector is.
Here, I believe, the Commission has significant tasks ahead of it, particularly in restructuring the East-West connection, such as Paris-Budapest, or the North-South axis.
Here, additional jobs can be created, which we currently urgently need in Europe.

Madam President, dear colleagues, there is no doubt that we have made progress in recent years towards gender equality. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are pushed into low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, socially insured employment has often been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure working conditions.
there especially women.
The Eurasian employment development from 2000 to 2010 includes 60% new, precarious, and atypical employment relationships, with two-thirds of these predominantly being women.
Women are often denied democratic participation through their part-time employment and precarious work in companies.
Women today are, however, significantly more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
They still earn 25 percent less than men on average.

We have dealt with this topic very intensively in the Employment Committee and have developed good proposals for the question of women's employment. Inclusion, regardless of the status of their work in

social security systems, the establishment of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems with the goal of independent living, and the organization of work according to the principles of good work.
All of this has essentially been incorporated into the report as precarious employment of women.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the outcome of this work and requests approval of the presented report. Thank you.
Yes, thank you, Madam Chair. Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, landmines will likely remain a significant problem even in the distant future.
Do you believe it is feasible to launch independent research programs aimed at detecting landmines?
This is not just a European problem, it is a global problem.
And can you envision identifying suitable institutions here that engage with research programs in this field?

Colleagues, in the transatlantic dialogue, there are many things that unite us. These are fundamental values and basic rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also several aspects that divide us, namely the application and specification of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Above all, when it comes to security issues, this contradiction becomes strikingly evident time and again.
Data protection is a constant source of misunderstandings. We have known this for a long time.
Therefore, if we manage to obtain a very good framework agreement, it will be a significant step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the respective partner.
A second important point where we have similar fundamentals but vastly different approaches is climate protection.
Therefore, I strongly desire for this to become a topic of discussion and for it to be addressed clearly.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments. Thank you.
For the first time, investment fund managers are facing a degree of transparency and regulation in this opaque thicket of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It is still possible to access the common market with unregulated products through passive distribution.
In essence, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to extend its rules internationally and achieve uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, and contrary to the Parliament's wishes, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
It remains the case that national rules alone determine the extent to which fund debt is permissible. And this means that the consequences of the crisis are not being drawn at this point.
There will be a national downward spiral in regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are private equity investments that make sense for companies,
But the rules now in place fall far short of being sufficient, unfortunately.
The information rights of employees, who rightly expect them, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of exploitation, are not effectively enforced.
Therefore, it is very difficult to justify this to the voters in this case.

Unfortunately, this is the case. The responsibility does not lie with the Parliament, but rather with the intense lobbying efforts of the respective industry, which have been particularly successful with the British government.

Government, specifically the French government, but I must unfortunately say also partly the German government, and we had representation of these lobbies here in Parliament, primarily in the form of the liberal faction.
We cannot agree to this proposal, as it would set a precedent for the Parliament's failure to enforce effective rules.
It is not possible for us to stand before our voters with our heads held high and say that we have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadow realm.
We hope to make progress on revising the policy then.
Many thanks once again, especially for the collaboration here with my colleagues in Parliament.
Yes, thank you very much. First of all, I would like to extend my sincere thanks to colleague Walz for his collaboration.
I can only emphasize this, even with differing perspectives, it has been a good collaboration.
Many believed, as I would like to emphasize here, many believed that the crisis in the euro area was over.
Ireland demonstrates that this has not been the case.
Europe continues to voluntarily submit to the financial markets.
The member states of the EU must continue to peddle their government bonds on the bazaar of financial markets and gain the trust of speculators through self-destructive austerity measures.
Over the weekend, we had to observe again where this is leading.

This time, it was not the allegedly fraud-prone Greeks, but model student Ireland, that was driven into the European rescue fund to save its banking system, which had also long been considered exemplary, indeed exemplarily deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already eyeing Portugal's capitalization, as its interest rates continue to rise.
The ECB bears a share of the responsibility for this drama.
She has failed and continues to fail to offer a civilized alternative to the state casino through the issuance of Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe recovers from the crisis, the ECB calmly watches as the other half sinks deeper into poverty and insecurity.
The collapse of entire economies may be to the taste of European fund and bank crises, but it helps neither Ireland nor the currency union nor the ECB.
Mr. Trichet, do not heed Ms. Merkel's simplistic ABC of finance.
If you want to save the Economic and Monetary Union, do not leave European government bonds hanging in the air.
Introduce Euro-Bonds before the next victim of speculation falls.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, considering how we debated this Commission proposal during the last parliamentary term, ranging from total rejection to jubilation over the wonderful things headed our way, I must say I am enthusiastic about what is now before us.
And here, the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs deserve great thanks for synthesizing a coherent opinion from this wide range of views.
I believe the magic word lies in the focus on the patient.
One did not, therefore, consider the many side effects, but rather asked, what does the patient need?
I believe it is correct that we have decided that the patient can inform themselves through various means and not just one.
However, I would like to emphasize that the doctor will still need to be the patient's trusted advisor and will undoubtedly have an influence on crucial decisions.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for it, and the information the patient receives has been checked and approved by a regulatory authority.
This ensures that the information is scientifically grounded and can thus be safely utilized by the patient.
Of course, it is correct, not everyone can determine this.
about the internet. For this, we have various methods, and I believe that it is so widely spread that we don't need to worry about it.
I only hope that the Council now finally has the courage to tackle this issue.
It is very important, action must be taken quickly.
Patients expect that.
I believe then that we have accomplished a great deed. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, coal is an undisputed part of energy supply.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization cannot be the right approach.
The question now is whether the deadline should be 2014 or 2018.
Colleague Rabka has presented a wealth of insightful arguments that I need not reiterate.
And my request to the Commission is simply this: there is clearly a large majority in all the committees involved in the Parliament in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the question of the deadline, the necessary flexibility is simply created, which is certain to also provide the opportunity for Member States to implement it and to ensure that the burdens on people, jobs, and economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that was mentioned, which, incidentally, was also in contrast to the Commission's impact, which also initially seems to be in favor of 2018, was the argument that climate policy reasons could play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect again. It makes no difference for the climate issue whether one burns foreign coal or one's own coal.

And my request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year period, when it comes to the Parliament, and if such a new line of argumentation arises in the Council, could not lead to the Commission also being able to show some flexibility.
I understood the hint to mean that the Commission is giving this matter thought, and I would like to express my gratitude for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, if we are to draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, indeed hold the presidency, it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.

We may have differing opinions on this point or that. But if, as Europeans, we speak with multiple voices there, our influence will not be credible. And if we are not credible, others will not follow us.
Why should they?
Therefore, I believe it is right that the figures we agreed upon at the end of 2007 under Chancellor Merkel must essentially remain in place and form the basis of these negotiations.

I share your view that the ambitious goals of 2 degrees should not be seriously questioned today to be reduced to a significantly lower temperature, as this makes the feasibility of these goals exceptionally difficult and risks losing public support.
I have a great concern that we are calling our intellectual property into question.
So our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now go and loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes as they are at the moment, then our valuable assets, namely our property, will walk away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a reason to invest in it. Therefore, intellectual property rights should not be strengthened.
As far as obligations are concerned, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
but they must be credible and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we will do exactly the opposite of what we want, namely, they will distance themselves from us.
so appearing credible in Cancun is an important point
The truly major decisions will be made later in Johannesburg. But in Cancun, I believe, we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in good condition, there will be no harvest.
Let's focus on the good soil.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. President, there was an incident during the debate on the European Council this morning that I do not wish to dwell on further, as I was the target of an insult.

I would like to say, however, that there are levels on which I cannot be offended and where I do not perceive it as an insult, because in order to offend me, one must possess a certain degree of sincerity.
I would like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless displays of solidarity I have received here in this house since then.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude to all of you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I believe this is a sign of our shared, democratic, and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this House holds.
For that, my sincere thanks.

Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr Gosses, and dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, first of all, I am pleased that we have now taken this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system will be placed under direct European supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, for strong control over a sector that contributed to the crisis.

I would like to make one comment on this, dear Mr. Barnier. The selection processes for the new agencies are currently underway, and the effectiveness of these new agencies depends entirely on the quality of their staff.

And I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, it will truly be about expertise, independence from the financial industry they are meant to regulate, a clear commitment to serving the public interest, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that override these important criteria.
Moreover, much remains to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still lack genuine transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies. There is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings within the financial sector and in regulations governing the financial industry.
We face severe conflicts of interest, we clearly have market power due to three dominant providers, and we bear no liability for negligently produced ratings.
Therefore, Commissioner, I would like to request that it is positive that the consultation is now underway, and we are eagerly awaiting the results.
And I also believe that civil society in particular should participate in this consultation. But then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as brave as before, and let us jointly create legislation next year that truly solves the problems that still exist in the ratings market in a European manner.
We owe that to the citizens.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues. The harm that rating agencies can cause has been demonstrated in the past few months since the beginning of this year.
There is, therefore, an urgent need for action.
And therefore, I welcome the directive, particularly the fact that it would entrust ESMA with the supervision and registration of credit rating agencies.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and constructive proposals were lost in the negotiations over the report.
And I would like to note this again here.
The mandate of ESMA thus remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database to create ratings have been dropped. Similarly, there is no mention of establishing a public rating agency.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by supervisory authorities has fallen by the wayside.
The Commission had further proposed promoting unsolicited ratings to overcome the disastrous issuer mandates for evaluating financial market products. Nothing came of that either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the upcoming reports on this topic, as mentioned by Jean-Paul Groset and also by you, Mr. Barnier. Thank you.
Mr. Chair, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, let me express my gratitude to those who worked on this report, especially to my colleague Benzen.
I would like to draw attention to two perspectives and perhaps give you something to ponder.
We agree that energy efficiency, using energy sparingly, is the solution. The simplest and most reasonable one.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to ask what benefit we have actually gained from repeatedly approaching people in Parliament with new and higher percentage figures.
Have we truly achieved more and made a greater impact?
Or why and at which points has energy been used more sparingly?
that the energy-intensive industry is more frugal with energy because it saves money and because it is advantageous for them.
And I learn that people, when they know that this device consumes more or less energy, and when they can see that and decide for themselves what the benefit is, will then make a decision accordingly.
perhaps not to work with percentages at all, but to use the method of properly advancing through incentives.
Second question. The commissioner has just presented very compellingly and clearly how complicated it is to even describe the term "What is it actually?"
How differently does this occur in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the member states are also in vastly different situations, economically, geographically, completely diverse.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, to work with a binding number, or do we need to come up with something more?

I believe that in energy policy, we need to break away from the past debate, which thinks it can achieve something with simple figures, binding targets, and so-called silver bullet solutions. Because clearly, we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should try the other approach, the differentiated one, that considers the diverse responses, the different situations, and sensibilities, but then also achieves an impact.
It is a question of the effects. It is not a question of our feelings.
The regulation being discussed today has long received little attention in all committees.
Now, at the end, when the result was presented, some people in this house woke up.
Unfortunately, some are not present for the debate right now. It would have been very, very interesting to hear your opinion as well.
As a former member of the Convention, the spirit of the Convention is still very, very vivid in my memory.
who has clearly demanded in many areas that the European Parliament must be given certain rights in order to have and maintain its credibility within the institutions and vis-à-vis the citizens.
In that sense, what the convent has set before us has not yet been granted.
These were extremely difficult negotiations, conducted in particular by the Belgian Presidency with the Council, which allowed for some important progress to be made.
I recall what colleague Lehne already stated, which was the issue of the constant possibility of verifying whether the Commission has exceeded its competencies.
Of course, there are some less than ideal arrangements, such as international trade agreements, but nevertheless, I can agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian Presidency.
She truly went above and beyond to ensure something was done, and our rapporteur, who negotiated with heart and mind.
13 On behalf of our group, I would like to make the following statement. This is a motion that my colleague Göran Färm tabled on behalf of our group in the Committee on Budgets.
We did not reintroduce this amendment, but the Green Group did, with 40 signatures from Green members.
We will abstain from voting on this motion.
I have reached an understanding with my colleagues from the Green Party. We are in complete agreement on this matter.
Since we have fundamentally stated that we are not submitting a new amendment as a faction at this time, we abstain.
I would like to expressly state that we support this point on financial transaction tax and hope that colleagues from the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
And this is particularly important in the case of cross-border services. Here, equal treatment is required.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retrospective price limits were employed for crisis management.
This is unacceptable, especially in the financial, insurance, and trading sectors, but also in the energy industry, which are heavily impacted here.
I hope that this will not also be employed in the field of healthcare services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orban to review these regulations, as they fundamentally violate the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the issues of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis available regarding the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are also hardly any mature calculations and analyses available for the new proposals.
I may state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
The examination of reality, however, also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for completely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration to the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers are not given the opportunity to profit in the billions from the fate of humans by exploiting our asylum laws.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and meticulous manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, the Commission has included corresponding obligations in the new drafts.
I consider many of these to be correct, such as interpreters, proper medical treatment, and taking into account special vulnerability.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
Member state authorities are provided with far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of conducting accelerated proceedings and summary proceedings should be restricted to a reasonable extent.

When an applicant flagrantly breaches their duty to cooperate, there are hardly any sanction options available. On the contrary, if they go into illegal hiding, the member state should not be able to conclude their procedure negatively. If they resurface, they should have an expanded range of procedural options at their disposal.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an accelerated procedure should be possible after the second subsequent application.
This entails significant cost increases.
Even the free legal advice in the form of a lawyer, according to the current wording of the Commission's draft, represents a significant cost increase for the states.
I simply and earnestly request the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals on practical reality, financial implications, and administrative issues for the member states.
We aim for a high standard, but it must also be achievable and, above all, it must not place excessively burdened member states before completely impossible tasks.
Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor briefly once again.
I have a great request of you, Commissioner Fühle.
I want to begin by stating that false assumptions lead to incorrect cost estimates.
We are currently not seeing a decrease in the number of asylum seekers, but rather a significant increase.
This is related to visa facilitation, for example with Serbia and North Macedonia.
We are currently also witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in an attempt to enter a country of the European Union.

When one proceeds from the false assumption that denying the first instance in a higher-qualified reform would save costs in subsequent instances, one automatically assumes that all member states, so to speak, have a poor first instance procedure.
That, however, is not the case.
Raising standards across the board inevitably leads to increased costs as a consequence.
An increase in quality standards for all involved and also the complication of processes, I am happy to discuss, leads to higher costs in practical reality.
Therefore, I once again kindly urge you to genuinely take into account the concerns of the countries, as the practical reports from the countries are partly available and will also be provided.
Many thanks, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, the Commission is commended for its successful competition policy in this report.
It must not be forgotten, however, that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the widening gap between rich and poor.
Unrestricted competition still takes precedence over the social needs of the people in the European Union.
The credo of free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are incapable of permanently establishing social justice.
A few proceedings related to distortion of competition and price-fixing simply do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time social internal market only functions with strong and just regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.
It is, for instance, unacceptable to continually expose public services to private-sector competition.
The report sets out guidelines for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the exemption of public services from competition rules, and the control of cartels—all of this is urgently needed.
Moreover, a contractual clause for secured social progress is necessary, which is at least on par with the competition rules in Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is a truly significant moment that we are commemorating the Holocaust of the Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament today.
And let me begin with the farewell letter written by a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, in 1943, before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote that I had found my parents again.
We are en route to the concentration camp.
I have come to terms with my inner self to the extent that I can bear death.
I would like to express my gratitude once again for everything you have done for me.
Greetings to all, farewell until we meet again in heaven.
Your Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500,000 other Roma and Sinti. And although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrial mass murder, the full truth about it remains unspoken even today, 66 years later.
And the complicity of the majority society is often concealed as well.
We need the full truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust against Roma and Sinti must be punished as a crime against humanity and acknowledged to ensure that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
We must put an end to racist harassment and violence, as occurred, for instance, in Hungary two years ago. We can do so through civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not the privilege of individuals but the right of all, for human and civil rights are indivisible. Thank you.
Yes, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, in my view, the focus now is on truly harnessing the potential of law.
to exploit the potential for strong financial supervision in Europe. And we have doubts as to whether these possibilities are truly being exhausted institutionally.
We observe shortcomings in the procedure. Until today, we as Parliament have not received the list of candidates in advance, but only the final result.
It would be straightforward for us to send these to the Executive Directors now.

We have a clear lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and due to certain incidents in the process, we doubt that the member states are truly filling this institution in the European interest.
and the further points in our letter legitimize the asking of a fundamental question.
But beyond that, of course, it concerns the suitability of individual persons. And here, each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There we see two major problems.

In hearings, we experienced that one of the candidates denied that it is a European institution, instead speaking of a network of supervisory authorities, and was not willing to correct this even when asked to do so.
When asked if they were prepared to make all lobbying contacts with the financial industry transparent, we did not receive clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the voting result depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. President, we, the Social Democratic faction, are submitting the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the House that we formulate it a bit more precisely.
We are dealing with a rather enormous influx.

Italy, like every other Mediterranean country, is certainly overwhelmed and unable to tackle the current problem alone. And Italy will undoubtedly not be the only country facing this massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with the problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, our request would be to formulate the title of the debate very precisely as follows: a statement by the Commission on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected by the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

By implementing the regulation, it will be possible to achieve, firstly, a high level of protection in the field of road passenger transport, comparable to the standard of other transport operators, for all passengers, including those with restricted mobility.

achieves results for people, secondly ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly takes into account the particularities that this is a transport sector largely shaped by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This means that the extreme subsidies, which would have made bus transport almost entirely impossible due to excessive funding, are off the table, just like subsidies where the majority of member states would have been completely excluded from the scope of the regulation.
Public bus services, which are of general benefit to citizens, must also provide high-quality transportation for people with disabilities and those with reduced mobility.
You should have a right to assistance. In the interest of social integration, this should be provided free of charge.

Thank you very much, Madam Chair. I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Kanzian, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of brokering a compromise on this challenging file.
There were successes, which have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties that have already been outlined.
With this compromise on bus traffic, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent, and efficient framework program for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the EU's credibility with European citizens.
And to be credible, it is absolutely essential to respect the coherence of rights for the different modes of transport.
It cannot be done differently for the rights of airline passengers. Fundamentally different criteria apply, for example, for train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important when developing a framework program not to focus on the lowest and weakest standards, but rather that we do not lose sight of ambitious goals in the interest of the citizens.

Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues, we are in the midst of a major economic crisis, and we have been discussing it for months now, which is all true. However, we typically talk in headlines and then continue to make decisions here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is because even we in Parliament are not specific enough and not honest enough in our actions, but rather engage in headline politics.
What, then, truly drives growth and stability?
Are we ourselves contributing to handling finances more responsibly and wisely?
Do we truly critically examine whether we are making the right expenditures, or doesn't each one of us have a new idea every day about where we can spend more money?

If we do not have the strength to focus the financial resources on future projects, and that means conflict, debate, and decision-making, then it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research without providing the necessary means for it.
is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also pursue policies that encourage economic growth and do not spend every waking moment considering ways to disrupt industry or the economy.
We continue to cheerfully pass resolutions, constantly demanding new ones today that disrupt the economy in its developments.
Does anyone believe that the issue of binding energy-efficient settlements, to name just one example, contributes to driving forward the economy?
Do you truly believe that we have achieved economic success with the decisions you have often made regarding energy?
Or have we disturbed them?
And I would hope that we can be a bit more honest about this and make fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that truly move us forward.
This is more arduous, laborious, and will also lead to disputes, but that is the essence of democracy.
Yes, thank you. Colleagues, the call for a financial transaction tax is not new. For several years now, opponents of globalization have been demanding such a tax.
Yet just five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be feasible in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda of the European Parliament, along with a CO2 tax and Euro bonds, and I think that's a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments that Anni Podimata proposes in her report, and I believe we will also vote accordingly.
These are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on cutting expenditures.
Cutting public spending primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poor—in other words, those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
She is the second lever that can be adjusted to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, the main causes of the public debt crisis and the repayment of public debt can also be adequately addressed through the revenue side.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenue is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high indebtedness of public budgets is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debts, namely the assumption of the debts of private banks and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis by no means rests solely with the states.
It is therefore not only obvious but also politically necessary to make the financial sector pay its fair share.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved in repaying public debt as the main cause of it.
This is an important political signal that this report sends, if it is adopted as presented.
But likewise, we consider Eurobonds to be a meaningful and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints from some surplus countries that their interest burdens are increasing due to Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also profit from their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But anyone who wants a social Europe, anyone who wants the EU to remain united in the future, must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.

In conclusion, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that they will now finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been requested for over a year. Thank you.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the rescue packages were intended to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they are imposing brutal austerity measures on people while leaving the perpetrators unscathed. Moreover, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Mr. Hahn, it is absurd and it brings tears to one's eyes to hear this formal argumentation here, that none of this was ever intended to be socially political.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not a matter for the EU. This policy of the Commission is in flagrant contradiction to the very idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for a race to the bottom in terms of wage competition and social dumping.
There is talk of rigid wages that are to be reduced.
When it comes to wages, they should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, blind people are talking about color. Those who formulate such statements have absolutely no understanding of collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reduce the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I want to make it clear: this Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent the further erosion of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policies and punitive actions. Thank you.
Mr. Barroso, you are a clever man, but you did not answer my question.

Therefore, I am inquiring once again: when Mr. Oettinger states that we currently suspect that certain facilities that are online will not survive our stress tests, am I to understand that you are aware that these facilities are so poorly secured that they cannot withstand the criteria?
Why then don't they intervene already today?
For in my eyes, that is a real danger.
Ms Gabriele Zimmer now has the floor. I would actually like to ask the two representatives of the Council and the Commission why they feel they need to approach this topic with hot air.

I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, especially in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the member states of the European Union and the European Union itself must take clear and concrete steps.
must finally fully honor its commitments to development aid and that it cannot be tolerated in any way for Member States to increasingly shirk this obligation.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still go hungry every day and that most of them live in LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

And it is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid does not go towards promoting and establishing agricultural structures, but that this share has rapidly decreased in recent years. With one billion hungry people,
And then to speak of our hope that the LDCs will become more shock-resistant, I'm starting to find that slowly cynical.
I call on you to address the problems specifically and clearly, and to make concrete commitments to actually assist the LDCs.
In the context of the internal market principle, public procurement law, which governs the award of public contracts, is an essential component.

Mr. Barnier, if you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I must ask you: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, and I have heard little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
This belongs to the basic rules that, as you say, you yourself do not want to call into question.

If one wishes to protect fundamental rules, it is necessary in future to ensure, when awarding public contracts, that elementary social standards are protected, that collective bargaining agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
This belongs to a modernized public procurement law.
And I explicitly state, fundamental social rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want perpetual conflict with the people who are turning away from this Europe, where they do not see their vital interests being protected. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner Krus, radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and consideration for the broader societal implications.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Program assumes a highly significant role.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into account economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be utilized to the fullest extent across all frequency bands, in order to generate maximum efficiency.

The foundation of radio frequency policy must be the Telecoms Package adopted last year. For it was here that it was also determined that EU and member state radio frequency management must equally serve cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be taken into particular consideration when harmonizing frequency usage in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I is currently being pursued at very different speeds in the Member States.
Further opening up of the ORF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions are still not definitively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities during technical upgrades, for example in the field of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
In the allocation of frequency bands, the differing interests must be responsibly balanced against each other.

Universal access to mobile broadband networks, on the one hand, is a fundamental requirement in the interest of European citizens. At the same time, however, further development in the field of public and private broadcasting as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity must also be taken into account.
We must set the course for technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn, I would like to say first of all, as you have described it, the situation has deteriorated.
The eurozone is experiencing a divergence between countries that are recovering and those that are faring weaker.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries are rising ever higher.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As the Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: in the ECB system's Day-2 customers, liabilities and claims between the central banks have piled up to over 400 billion euros.
This is due to the fact that banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities not provided for in the Eurosystem?
Then the major problem, why we are not making progress with debt restructuring, is that the banking system, as Ms. Ford also stated, is not properly structured.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When does the Commission submit this?
And how do you, as the Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?

and we are seeing rising resource and food prices, at least if we discount the recent ups and downs.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. President, Ms. Kinga Göns is a member of my group.
