Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, and dear visitors, the cultural diversity of Europe is a valuable asset that we must preserve and continue to foster in the future.
To make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the field of the cultural and creative sectors.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value but also a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately 2.5% of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many areas of the rest of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content provided by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of this content have been transformed and enhanced by technology.
We therefore need framework conditions for the cultural and creative industries that enable them to develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
The culture and creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
Therefore, we must also pay attention to this area in the context of school and vocational education.
We need to impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
We must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators. And not just entrepreneurial competencies, but also good media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions that enable cultural creators to secure their livelihood.

And therefore, we will have to deal intensively with the issues of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, but also with open access to information and content, in order to further develop...

to ensure the future of the creative and cultural industries in a digital environment and to also be able to preserve Europe's cultural diversity and cultural heritage as an essential feature of the European Union.
Mr. President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues, today we commemorate in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions rank among the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was not least of all, and not inappropriately, dubbed an era of expulsions.
And we all bow our heads today in remembrance of the victims of these inhuman acts.
We demand a comprehensive elucidation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism in this context.

And today's Russia should not perceive this as a political attack, but rather as support for coming to terms with its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is characterized by both light and shadow.
But as we remember the victims from the Baltic countries, we also remember the Armenians who were driven out of Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We commemorate the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a particular peak in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav Wars.
We must also not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious confrontation with the various forms of expulsions and the bogus justifications.
And this also includes clarifying the guilt and punishing the guilty, insofar as this is still possible, as is now the case with Mladic, for example.

But the crucial answer lies in European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European unification process, which is still ongoing.
This historic task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but above all to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries of Europe, both East and West, have worked on this.
Let's think, for example, of the Gdańsk Declaration, signed by Polish President Wozniowski and German Federal President Rauch.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must remain vigilant, even towards the first signs of expulsions, such as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the idea that Arab immigrants should be sent back across the Mediterranean in boats. And we must resist those who seek to undo Europe's borderless achievements and revert to a new, narrow-minded nationalism.
Let us bow in reverence to all the victims of expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously affirm the continuation of European integration as the only true guarantee against a
Politics that brought so much misfortune upon the people of Europe, but also beyond, in the past century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have not lost any of their validity. They are best preserved in a united Europe. Thank you.

Many thanks, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. I had the opportunity, as a parliamentary election observer, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan. And I was impressed by the overwhelming consent of the South Sudanese to determine the future of their country themselves.
And I also witnessed the great expectations among the people, who viewed the independence of their country as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called Internally Displaced Persons, driven from their homes in the south by decades of conflict and sheltered in refugee camps in the north, are now embarking on the journey back to their former South Sudanese homeland.

And of course, the people of South Sudan, alongside the independence of their country, above all desire to live in peace and walk a path towards a happier future, after all those decades of warlike conflicts in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is set to become officially independent, expanding the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are about as bad as they could be. And, of course, much has already been said about this here.
70% of the people live as nomadic pastoralists, 80% are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also intensifying, and according to observers' estimates, more than 1000 people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and violated are barely counted.
Sudan was already among the failed states.
There is a risk that the state of South Sudan is already starting out as a failed state.
I firmly believe that Europe has a great obligation to this region.
In light of the colonial past of these countries, the European Union's common foreign policy is called upon to act in cooperation with the UN and the African Union. It can also prove itself here.
It is not just about money, but also about supporting the fragile, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate firmly with those who hold the fate of the country in their hands, namely the tribal leaders, the leaders of the military groups, to ensure they do not dash the hopes of their people in the country. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. I am very grateful to colleague Bartolozzi for making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament through his initiative on this question.
While the formerly Soviet states of Central Asia are now addressed from various perspectives in Parliament, Mongolia and its situation have only been sparingly reflected here.
It was indeed, quite unjustly, Mongolia that, as a state of the former communist bloc, made early use of its independence and embarked on a path towards the democratization of its society.

As early as 1992, the Mongols adopted a democratic constitution, and several elections have taken place since then, which, according to observers, have been democratic and fair overall—a fact that is by no means a given in the states of this region.

The Mongolian government has been attempting for several years to combat corruption in the legal system and imposed a moratorium on the death penalty in 2010, something that even some major democratic states have not yet achieved to date.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this vast country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
Thus, a rural population, still largely nomadic to this day, is flooding into the few cities, which are not infrastructurally prepared for this.
The country's mineral resources are not being extracted in an environmentally friendly manner.
Energy problems are hindering civilian and economic life.
Squeezed between its large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia risks falling even more strongly into the dependency of these states.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia—and here I see the glass as half full rather than half empty—in democratizing its society should be acknowledged, as they are exemplary for this region and demonstrate what is possible despite a challenging past.

And Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only through aid programs, but also through the direct presence of the European Union in the Mongolian capital with its own negotiation office.

Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia and Europeans is not indifferent and that European interests should not continue to be represented from the legation in Peking. One more sentence, please.

Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, the significance of regional cooperation on the internet will continue to grow in the future.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. After nearly three years of intense work, after well over 3,000 amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it is now ready for voting. The political package, the great compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of foodstuffs.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all. The European food industry is also intended to benefit.
Legal certainty, deregulation, and better regulation are the goals.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises. And it is crucial to understand that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80 percent SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must fit every food and non-alcoholic beverage. From staple foods to highly processed ready-to-eat meals.
Therefore, a mandatory labeling system using traffic light colors is not feasible, as this type of labeling simply does not apply to staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in the Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved can certainly be seen as a success.
Allergens will be immediately recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is stated.
There is a country of origin labeling for pork, poultry, sheep, and goat meat.

For further products, an impact assessment will indicate whether and how the origin can be specified, for example, for milk and dairy products, single ingredients, i.e., products consisting of one main ingredient, meat in processed goods.
Products, etc. Imitations must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to formed meat and formed fish, composed of, or glued together from, small pieces.
A package must not give the impression that it contains something that it does not.
If an image of fruit is on a yogurt, it must also contain fruit, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, there is the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients, always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters, for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be indicated, the date of the first freezing for meat and fish, and many more details.
The most important thing, however, is that all information must be legible.
We have defined readability, established a minimum font size, and mandated the Commission to set binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the text and the background.
At the same time, we protect craftsmanship from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh products must provide allergen information, but not the complete, expensive-to-determine nutritional information through detailed analyses.

The Commission initially sought this, but it would have destroyed national and regional peculiarities and specialties. It would have resulted in a European homogenization, which is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed and the reputable consumer protection advocates are indeed satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, and in particular Commissioner Dalli for his statements, which he will hopefully make shortly and which will untie the knot that has formed in our political discourse.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, given the currently exceptional situation as a result of the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
Only in this way can we restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report focuses on the strategy to prevent infinite human suffering, resulting from approximately 35,000 annual deaths and disabilities.
4.5 million often severe injuries resulting from road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of an associated economic loss of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone corresponds to the number that would be expected from the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized passenger aircraft.
What would we not do to prevent that?
The accident-related costs exceed the annual overall budget of the European Union by a significant margin.
Therefore, I am confident that it is beneficial for us to engage in sustainable activities in this field.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have succeeded for the first time with this report in developing a unified, holistic, and coherent approach to improving road traffic safety.
It takes into account the content of the UN Charter for Road Safety 2010-2020 as well as the content and objectives of road safety work in the EU member states and broad sections of civil society.
It encompasses, firstly, ambitious yet realistic goals for the period up to 2020 and, with the vision of Sirum, for the period beyond.
Thus, by 2020, the number of fatal accidents is to be reduced by 50 percent, the number of children killed by 60 percent, and the number of seriously injured people by 40 percent.
This is in the utmost interest of each and every one of our citizens, as well as in our national economy.
We recommend that member states adapt goals and methods to their own territories and expect them to develop their own road safety action programs.
Secondly, it encompasses who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In the spirit of subsidiarity, the holistic approach entails that Member States, regional or locally responsible enterprises, and indeed every individual road user, in accordance with their duty to cooperate, have a responsibility to act.
And it includes thirdly, how, that is, with which instruments, activities, and measures the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not wish to do without guidelines, recommendations, and commissions.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity. This means that competencies and responsibilities have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

Since they come from the most diverse general directorates such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the appointment of a Road Safety Coordinator within the European Commission.
This effectively prevents the establishment of a road traffic safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main areas of action have been identified.
They concern humans as participants in traffic, road traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructures, their intelligent networking, as well as the particular consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request approval for tomorrow.

special consideration must be given, and this is also included, and I believe it is important and positive that vulnerable road users are finally being brought into the spotlight, and I hope that these measures will ultimately be implemented.

on the condition that industries in Europe, which are thereby unduly burdened, can be relieved, as they would otherwise not be able to compete with other regions of the world.

we are facing a completely new situation, we are dealing with a much more competitive environment

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to begin by thanking the representative of the Council for his very clear description of the current situation.
In this debate, we have continually heard that it is about improving the situation for working women who are deciding to have a child.
In my view, the directive places too much emphasis on increasing maternity leave to 20 weeks.
But do we truly believe that the decision for a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity protection?

As the mother of three children, I am well aware that comprehensive concepts for offerings and good family-friendly options are essential to positively influence the decision to have children and to promote equal opportunities for women.
The present draft guidelines fall far short of addressing the diverse, sometimes very good service and overall concept proposals in certain member states.
We need flexible solutions that address the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking will not lead to a solution here.
Therefore, we first need to develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
And the comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children are of the highest priority here.
This can be ensured in various ways with different models.
Those who want to bash their way through the wall with their heads don't necessarily reach their goal faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors or build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution for enhancing maternal protection in order to make progress on this issue.

I believe that we truly need to find a new approach, based on the Commission's draft guidelines, which offers more flexibility for different concepts in the individual member states, in order to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also the protection of children in their first months of life.
This does not work with the draft that is presented here today, which certainly did not have the broad majority, as some colleagues tried to make clear today.

I would like to see a little more flexibility and a bit more realism here, and a somewhat better recognition of what the member states have already achieved today, without calling our fundamental demands into question.
Yes, Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would be sensible, and instead of plugging loopholes for tax avoiders, they have created a Swiss cheese with large holes here.
The planned transition period of five months allows ample time and opportunity for tax evasion, as it provides time to transfer funds from Switzerland to other tax havens.
However, as foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is sufficient to convert the assets held in Switzerland into foundation assets.
Corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
Some time ago, the tax investigation authorities in Germany were provided with information about several tax offenders who are hiding their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals an amnesty, and tax investigators are no longer permitted to use the information at their disposal against them.
What kind of agreement is it that puts the tax investigation on a leash?
In a promotional video for Swiss banks, it is stated accordingly about this agreement: in the future, customers will benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial center.

This agreement clearly lacks not only the necessary coordination at the EU level. It also runs counter to the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection more efficient in the member countries, and above all, to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, this cannot be acceptable from our perspective.
this agreement, and we ask the EU to also strongly oppose it in case of doubt. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Madam President. I am pleased that we have succeeded in jointly putting forward a sustainable and effective directive with the report by Roberta Angelilli. And I would like to thank her for this.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.

In this context, education is of utmost importance, as many teachers and parents are unaware of what can be achieved with their children's computers and mobile phones.

It is therefore welcome that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, as authorities, but also schools and families, must do everything in their power to prevent such heinous crimes from occurring in the first place.
As a result, the EU also requires better negotiating strategies with third countries such as the USA and Russia.

And pages stored outside the EU can only be deleted effectively and quickly if we also work closely with these countries in the hunt for the perpetrators and together send a clear signal condemning the sexual abuse of children.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, as well as deleting before blocking, jurisprudence, education, and intensive scientific documentation of the facts must continue to be advanced even after the vote tomorrow.
It is the case that we by no means can rest on our laurels.
Instead, we must all embrace the call to action, each one of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Thank you, Mr. President. For years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at roughly the same level.
Meanwhile, the tasks of the EU have constantly expanded, and the financial requirements have increased significantly.
Thus, the necessary new institutions have been established with the financial market supervisory authority.
To effectively fulfill their tasks, however, these institutions require a sound financial endowment.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become undeniable.
To strengthen the economies of these countries, a comprehensive stimulus program would be necessary.
Some economic experts even speak of the necessity of a Marshall Plan for the crisis-stricken EU countries.
The EU does not need growth-destroying austerity programs, but rather a growth-promoting spending program that ensures work and income for employees, for young people in the EU.
But what does the council do in this situation?
He cuts the Commission's proposal, which already falls far short of what is needed.

If, in the current political climate, a proper increase in the budget is not feasible, then Parliament and the Commission should at least do everything in their power to fend off the cuts proposed by the Council. Thank you.
until it becomes more difficult. Ms. Zimmer, you have the laptop, please. Yes, thank you, Ms. Zimmer. Ladies and gentlemen, the current crisis reveals the kind of European Union we actually want.
Do we want a union where the binding force, the glue, is the conviction that it matters to us whether people in any country within the European Union have to live in poverty?
We see it as our shared responsibility to combat poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we opt for a union as outlined by the colleagues from the far-right factions of this very parliament.
Sometimes I believe that with the attitude of the member states and in particular some of their governments, we are dangerously close to the vision of a European Union as formulated by the far-right.
Refrain from doing anything jointly, do not establish shared tools, do not set common indicators, use vague formulations wherever possible.
The third report makes this very, very clear in many respects, and I believe we need to become significantly stronger in this area.
What we need is an immediate halt to the fire sale of public goods, the fire sale of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
In light of the impending winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death due to rising energy prices.
Here we share a joint responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for this, not for the nationalist ramblings we have heard from the right-wing side.
What would we have advised our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when we were in the midst of the Depression, when financial markets had already undermined democracies, and as we were heading towards war?
I believe two things are necessary. Two emergency measures. We need something akin to a transitional government.
Do what you must do quickly. Don't let yourself be held back. Regulate every product, every institution, and every player as strictly as Ms. Müller does.
What Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, enforcing the financial policy emergency program, cannot have a future if there is no democratic policy emergency program.

And that means in this case, of course we need a European community, of course we need different treaties, of course we need a functioning instrument, but one that is only legitimate and gains legitimacy when there are popular referendums.

And for this, we need to raise awareness now, as the situation has become so dramatic that a complete change of mindset is necessary before the right-wing, before the national divisors, regain control over something that was actually already built.
Many thanks, Madam Chair. There is no doubt that this House stands for transparency and openness towards the citizen.
Of course, my EPP Group does the same.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual objective.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are being ignored. The protection of competitive procedures, sensitive and personal data is being disregarded.
This is a serious breach of data protection, for which we otherwise always advocate so strongly in other areas.
Should we now sacrifice the privacy of the global public?
The present report poses precisely this risk, as administrative processes and decisions, which after all also encompass personnel matters, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information within the context of approval procedures, court proceedings, and competition law proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report permits public access to such documents as well. For, as a document, it defines all data and content that are in any way related to the policies, measures, and decisions of all organs and institutions of the EU.
This includes, to a large extent, preparatory, confidential, and secret documents as well as all related information.
And thus, this definition encompasses not only documents but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, should also be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, for indeed, what that means?

It means public access to the process. It means public influence on the decision-making procedure. We might as well invite the lobbyists to the table and let them negotiate. Is that what the citizen wants?
I cannot imagine it.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative organization, etc., are also to be published. Where is the public interest in this?
Or would it rather hinder our work?
I believe this report was not created in the interest of our citizens.
It would trigger a flood of useless information.
He would render our work impossible, and above all, as you have heard from the Commissioner, he is unacceptable to the other institutions because he violates existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and in essence, you are working against greater transparency and against the citizen. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, when dealing with such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a significant risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to incorporate their two or three desired issues.
When one considers the result that will be put to the vote tomorrow, one can without doubt congratulate our rapporteur, Mathieu Grosch.

He managed to distill a good, coherent, and comprehensive result from several hundred proposed amendments, placing the main emphasis for the transport of the future on safety, environmental protection, energy, and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are also adequately addressed here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming shortage of skilled workers in the transportation sector, which must be actively addressed if future bottlenecks in highly qualified personnel are to be prevented.
Further openings of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given significant attention here.
Road safety is an issue that must continue to occupy us in the future as well.
I view other points more critically.
I would have liked to see a statement on the model ship that emphasized shifting more traffic from roads to rails and waterways.
And for this reason, I do not consider the discussion about Giga-liners to be the best solution for greater sustainability.
Similarly critical is the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport, which should be awaited and reconsidered.
Here, technical harmonization and fair competitive conditions still need to be addressed.
As stated in this report, I hope that the expectations of Parliament are not just a pious hope but that a goal will be achieved by 2020 and our proposals have become reality. Thank you.
It is only 20 years ago that the Central Asian states gained their independence as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
Emerging from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a persistent challenge.
Nevertheless, these countries, due to their wealth of natural resources and raw materials, are important trading partners of the EU and its member states.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to facilitate collaboration and promote partnership-based action, but not to lead to unilateral stigmatization.
Child labor, and particularly forced labor of children, is a sadly still prevalent evil in many countries of the world that must be combated.

I would like to point out, however, that it was common practice in many agriculturally dominated European regions to extend the school holidays for children during harvest time and provide those from farming families with the opportunity to help with the harvest, which no one today would label as forced labor.
If, however, there are indications of forced child labor in the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other states where child labor still exists, including those states where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as India or China.
We should not apply a double standard here.
Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues, I can only add my voice to those in the ranks who have congratulated the Council Presidency.
In times of difficulty, they were not only an honest broker, but they were also a European broker.

I think it was very reassuring to experience this in these challenging times, where we see political movements in several member states that imply to people that they could achieve more on their own than together.
and you have placed the common ground at the center.
And it was also very refreshing to experience that you also found agreement among the people in Poland in the domestic political debate with this clear European agenda.
It was not entirely straightforward in this context.
and also for that, the utmost respect for what you have achieved.
In this six-month period, we have been able to make significant progress, especially in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may single out just one area that I myself was involved in negotiating, namely the issue of regulation regarding short selling and naked credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission did not dare to propose strict regulations, we were confronted with resistance from all sides.

Member States were told that you will not prevail, and where it was successfully achieved, thanks to the Polish Presidency of the Council, to sanction a highly speculative instrument and, where necessary, also to prohibit it, so that we can contribute to greater stability in financial markets.
I would like to expressly thank your Minister of Finance and the State Secretary, who initiated this through a laborious process of discussion between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of how one can work together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. Steers, thank you for that.
As of yesterday, colleagues, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances is in effect.
The specific content regulations are now also available.
What developments does the Commission now consider dangerous? What economic problems does it seek to correct?
The Commission views an increase in unit labor costs in euro countries of more than 3% per year as a problem.
A limit for decreasing wages, however, is not provided.
Inexpensive, dear Commission, does not automatically mean good.
It is not sufficient to encourage member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health, and energy efficiency, we may exploit our workforce to the bone, but we will not create economic success stories this way.
Another example from the scorecard. The loss of export market shares is to be reviewed and sanctioned.
That is nonsense.
With the increase in global trade, Europe's shares, statistically speaking, inevitably decrease in
The indicator consequently penalizes countries that are already integrated into global trade.
Therefore, we believe that the Commission should withdraw this proposal and subject it to a complete overhaul. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by joining in the thanks extended to our rapporteur and all those who contributed to the report. This is not a routine matter, even though we are addressing competition policy for the 40th time based on a Commission report.

I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the Commissioner, as 2010 was the year in which you were fully responsible for competition policy for the first time, and for the very comprehensive presentation.

I would like to express the request, however, and you have just addressed this in your contribution as well, that we should, especially in the area of aids, public aids in the banking sector, come to a certain degree of processing.
should come, as due to the new stress test by the European Banking Authority, a new capitalization in the banking sector is already being called for again.
and I do not believe that this contributes to the stability of the banking system when we still have a multitude of unanswered or unresolved legacy issues on one hand.
In effect, we are already seeing new cases arise due to the pressure being applied to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the private banking sector.

So then, Commissioner, my urgent request is for a swift solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector in such a way that it can face up to the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic, merger control, will continue to occupy us intensively in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the continuation of the clear and transparent approach that the Commission has pursued to date within the framework of merger control.

I believe it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially consumers, that we ensure in the area of merger control that competition is possible even in larger or different structures—I do not want to pass judgment on this.
In that sense, thank you to all who have collaborated on this. And I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon reach a solution, especially in the banking sector. Thank you.

Commissioner, I believe you have just hit the nail on the head by collectively acknowledging that we are capable of launching a third industrial revolution in Europe if we recognize the sustainability opportunity as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke about resources, and that reminds me of a thought I completely forgot about today.
I indeed forgot the human resources in my office.
And Mrs. Philipp, please allow me to say, you toiled like a horse. Wonderful successes, you were a truly leading figure in this matter.
And for that, I would like to express my sincere gratitude.
Thank you, Mr. President. In order to ensure freedom of speech in Parliament, we also need a functioning microphone system.
The button to turn on the microphone has broken on my device.
I would like to request that a technician restore free speech. Thank you.
Many thanks, Madam President, Commissioner, and esteemed colleagues. It surprises me that we continually need to remind ourselves of what structural and cohesion policy actually entails.

Coalition and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union and, by definition, it aims to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, with a particular focus on promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of coalition and structural policy have been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
In many regions, the situation looks even more challenging. With regard to economic development, these resources would not be available.
The implementation of the funding structure is based on operational programs, as already mentioned, which outline the funding strategy for each respective region.
The European Union, Member States, and regions work in partnership here, thereby creating a genuine European added value.
The success of coalition and structural policy also depends on the reliability of the programs and the funds made available and committed.

Therefore, I am greatly surprised when, time and again, member states and also, as we now see, the Commission attempt to use Structural Fund resources like a piggy bank for all manner of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the meaning and purpose of coalition policy, and moreover unsettles the stakeholders in the regions who are already working towards achieving the goals based on long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important objectives.
This can only be achieved, however, if the partnership cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and if the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
For only you possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Coalition and structural policy is the unifying, partnership-based, solidaristic bond of action between the various political levels in the European Union.
In it, the solidarity of Europe becomes tangible in the regions, and it should not be recklessly abandoned due to political quick fixes. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr. Chair, Mr. Commissioner. I support the compromise found in the trialogue, which aims to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-à-vis the processing industry, even though I am aware that it does not solve all the problems currently facing dairy farmers in some Member States.
Even Commissioner Manzold had foreseen preferential measures within the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) 50 years ago to encourage the establishment of producer organizations.
Even in my country, Luxembourg, dairy farming, due to the high proportion of grassland, is the main pillar of our agriculture.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join a cooperative that takes over the processing of the milk itself.
Five Member States voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet the requirement of being a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission holds the right of initiative when it comes to legislative proposals, and therefore, I would like to urge you to present a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament by 2012 in order to rectify this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction in the super levy, which is incurred for every kilogram of milk delivered, up to 2015, or the abolition of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative impacts of the phasing-out regulation without harming the unaffected member states.
The present milk package also serves as a final report of the High-Level Group, aiming to ensure a soft landing for the phasing out of milk quotas.
Astonishingly, milk quotas are not mentioned at any point in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other member states, who are striving to prepare for the liberalization of the dairy market and expand their production,
want to remain competitive on the global market after 2015, they can only do so by purchasing additional quotas even now, shortly before the end of the milk quota system.
An enormous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure, which places them at a disadvantage compared to their colleagues in 22 member states. Thank you.
So, please, the Blue Cut. Question, are you aware that we have long had community bonds?
And that the resolution does not speak of Eurobonds in a blanket manner, but rather of very different options,
and are they aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment
I find it questionable that you have once again made generalizations about Eurobonds here.
It is precisely the level of detail that we have achieved here with Ms. Goulart's excellent proposal that we should not give up again.
I would like to hear a little more nuance in your statements and am curious to hear your thoughts on this.
I will just say briefly, dear colleague Gulda, this is not an evaluation that I have conducted.
I would like to point out that the last Italian government bond before Italy adopted the euro yielded 10%.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should take over now.
It was a given that one paid high interest rates.

And now suddenly, after ten years of low interest rates and excessive indebtedness, as money has become cheap, for investments as well as for public entities, one wants to prolong this through Euro-Bonds.
This is a trap from which we cannot escape, and I stand by that.
Warm thanks, Commissioner. Your response has genuinely left me somewhat disappointed.

They apparently want to cling to the old system, where complex negotiations must be conducted for each country, which in turn grants no further access to literature, thus creating no additional opportunities for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because now the European Union is blocking a step forward at the WIPO, while all or many other contracting partners would be ready to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

They are not fighting here for increased rights for copyright holders, but rather against people for whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is intended to guarantee equal access to cultural goods and ensure their full participation in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you, please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding treaty.

Dear colleagues, the discussion in this house shows that we essentially represent the full spectrum. On the one hand, those who do not wish for any restrictions, and on the other hand, those who associate any form of immigration immediately with the risk of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be viewed with a great deal of reason and also expressed with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed issues in member states where overly restrictive measures are being taken.
For family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited at all.
On the other hand, it is entirely justified for Member States to require, for example, language skills, to demand integration, but also to require the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, the member states, of course, have the right, and we should not set aside these issues, to articulate the problems that arise in family reunification.

If countries like Greece or like Malta, or indeed like Romania or Italy, are no longer allowed to articulate the problems they partly face in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic when we simply ignore problems.
I do not believe that we need another new guideline right now.
I believe we should discuss the problems carefully and then consider how we can eliminate them.
Continuously producing new guidelines does not lead to improved guidelines and their implementation.
We are currently experiencing some implementation issues.

And I also fully understand that we first need to come to terms with the fact that we should not be creating yet another new directive and adding to it before we have thoroughly discussed the old directive in all its problematic aspects.
I am in favor of listening to the Member States while also respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if we do this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will find a good path.
Mr. President, think, reflect, think. Consider before you think, urges the Polish aphorist Stanislaw Wierzylec. And this recommendation would also do us good in this Parliament from time to time.
Just a few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy was adopted in this House, in which the Central Asian states were given failing grades, strike events are now occurring in Janaozen.
in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being conducted with international participation, to be reflected.
As much as the dead must be mourned, and the injured and imprisoned in the aftermath of these events have the right to a reckoning with what has occurred, the backgrounds remain opaque.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, stated: "That was a group of other people. The riots are not in the interest of the strikers at all, as it only provides a reason to use force against them."
Central Asia expert Arkady Dubnov also stated, in a quote, that it is not excluded that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad might also be involved.
On the other hand, however, it could very well fit into someone's plans in the Kazakh capital Astana to keep the tensions simmering.
Ultimately, Kazakhstan's power elites are already vying for the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
Quote end. We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in the parliament.

UN Special Envoy Miroslav Jentschak announced today that he is impressed by the attention paid to the events in Zhanaozen by the Kazakh government and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of the unrest.
We should take the Kazakh authorities at their word, measure them by their actions, but avoid knee-jerk condemnations.
As I understand it, that is the statement you made today. Yes, the Commission is advocating for the continuation of the food program for the most deprived persons in the European Union.
She will do everything in the near future to also put concrete proposals on the table, a) where the program will be located exactly, b) how financing is to be achieved.
I consider this urgently necessary and believe that we bear a joint responsibility to ensure that this food program indeed becomes a reality.
not because I consider it the ultimate solution, but because in my view it is a signal to show people that we still have a fundamental sense of the necessary solidarity with the

the life situations of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, were unable to participate in development and who have become the first and greatest victims of the way the European Union has tackled the crisis.
I think here of Greece, I think of Spain, I think of other countries where precisely what we do as the European Union, above all at the expense of the poorest of the poor, is taking place.
We set a sign, but unfortunately, it is no more.

I therefore believe that it is urgently necessary for us to ensure, not only for the 18 million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food aid, that the food supply is secure and sustainable.

We must not simply be provided with resources, but rather, we need to ensure that the fight against poverty remains or is placed at the very top of our agenda, in the top spot on our own list of priorities.
We have not transmitted this signal so far.

From my perspective, this is the crucial point if we want to make further progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union in shaping a truly social and solidarity-based Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments, which have so far been blocking, must abandon this stance.
I believe this is also a form of self-commitment for us.
Esteemed colleague Dohl, I have been listening to you attentively.
What you are proposing, namely to introduce a growth test for all expenditures in parallel with the subsidiarity test, does in fact mean narrowing the focus to growth objectives.
I would like to know from you how you reconcile this with the claim of a Christian democratic faction that, after all, still pursues goals beyond growth.
It is generally known that the economy does not give birth to children that it does not raise, and that it cannot enable them to live a life in intact nature.
This suggests that the priorities should be revised by the Commission and also by the Council, that they should be rethought.
We will, as a faction, examine very closely whether what you presented earlier today indeed constitutes a change in priorities.
Previously, the mantra was that the economy comes first, and it requires functioning financial markets.
And that was the initial focus: to stabilize public finances, i.e., reduce debt and maintain calm in the markets.
And Mr. Dohl, who unfortunately is not present here today, to him I really only wanted to say that I would hold the same view as Georges Marchais.
Although I did not understand his answer, I would disagree with him.
I believe the measures that were initiated were simply wrong.
They were not correct. It was not right to focus exclusively on the recovery of the economy while completely ignoring what happened to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the euro above all else and say that we don't care at all what happens to the people.
It must be the other way around. First, it's about the people, then we can continue discussing Euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain drove the interest rates on Spanish government bonds above 6% and higher, thus approaching the interest level at which other countries like Greece, Portugal, or Ireland had sought support from the rescue fund.
And the austerity policies imposed on the member state by the EU, the ECB, and the IMF, with drastic reductions in all kinds of public expenditure.
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase in value-added taxes, and much more have burdened citizens with the costs and have not prevented the renewed spiral.
Severe cuts to government spending, exacerbating the economic downturn, drive up national debt ratios. And this must be our shared understanding.
When Mr Draghi recently stated that the European social model has come to an end, I am glad, Mr Barroso, that you say, no, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece and to Portugal, to Ireland, and to carefully register what is happening there.
What happens to the people who are currently fighting for their survival?
What happens or what do we do together to finally break the suicide spiral that has taken hold, especially in the most affected debt-ridden countries?
It cannot be that we simply stand by and watch here.
And we will not benefit from social policy programs that will eventually take effect once other measures have succeeded.
We must act now. What happened to your target objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty?
What has become of the European Poverty Platform?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
However, now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the European Union to take action.
They need no empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive the support of my faction.
Support all those who, even within the Commission, have recognized the signs of the times and want to bring about change.
But please don't just carry on and say it will all work out.
There will be nothing left if this continues. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, outlining how we can actively assist the people in the affected countries right now.
Do something about it.
We will have to do this in our countries to prevent the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 to 2020, or indeed for the other programs, from being reduced.
that the member states fulfill their responsibilities. Thank you.
Dear esteemed colleagues, the current situation of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a tax policy fairy tale hour.
The situation in the Council is quite straightforward: little progress is made on tax policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are opposed to further tax cooperation efforts,
They benefit from aggressive tax planning. They are themselves tax havens.
And the treaties clearly stipulate unanimity in tax matters.
Therefore, the EU Commission has suffered shipwreck on multiple occasions in the past with its proposals.

They are being watered down, they are not moving forward, as with the interest rate directive. And in more recent proposals, nothing substantial has been suggested at all, in a case of preemptive obedience.

Therefore, I ask you, Mr. Schimeter, I know your job is not easy in this regard. Change the strategy, propose stringent measures, and then rely on enhanced cooperation to end the blocking position in the Council.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, with the proposal at hand, it is certain that no state bankruptcy can be prevented through risk-sharing instruments where it should occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budget and debt crisis in some states has created such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures under cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented because the banking sector, as a financier, is no longer available and private investors are no longer accessible.
An extraordinary measure, in my view, is the proposal presented here to create risk-sharing instruments for the continued financing of projects in structural policy.
Cohesion and structural policy instruments available to countries wishing to use these division tools can be employed to financially secure already ongoing projects.
I am very grateful to rapporteur Danuta Hübner, who significantly contributed to refining the Commission's proposal and once again clearly outlined when and how these instruments should be utilized.
I am also of the opinion that these risk-sharing instruments should only be a response to the current situation and cannot set a precedent for the next funding period.
When an amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in 2009 required a review after three years and the presentation of four studies, our faction supported this.
And indeed also because it had repeatedly expressed great concerns due to data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefits of biometric data in passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method as well, and what then results from it, the underestimation of other links in the security chain are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this great misconception, namely the assumption that it is immutable and the most trustworthy.
And that is by no means the case.
Even these data are subject to change over the course of life.
In children, they simply look different than in old age.
And for this reason, too, reliable and serious studies and conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues unabated.
we have now been able to determine.
As incidents in Great Britain and other countries continually demonstrate, the chips are by no means secure against misuse.
They are cheerfully cracked and can mean permanent damage for those affected.
Standards within the EU are also exceptionally diverse.
The error rate is, as in France and the Netherlands, very, very high.
And again and again, the question must be asked: what use are biometric data to us when documents are forged and in circulation?
If, therefore, a link in the chain is forged, and the source documents are inconsistent, biometric data will not assist us further.
One last point. The Chaos Computer Club in Germany took only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club required the lid of a plastic bottle, some superglue, a digital camera, and a little wood glue. In just a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. That's all there is to the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies, and of course also the results and the consequences that follow from them. Thank you.
Esteemed Council, the Commission is unfortunately not adequately represented today as I would have wished in respect for Parliament.

As a representative from a region that will be severely affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, after carefully following the debate, I am compelled to ask whether the unfortunately rather inadequate attempt to...

a standardization of the criteria for disadvantaged areas that truly meets the needs of these regions. Especially since the necessary information for a meaningful and responsible decision is not available here.
Above all, I wonder whether a truly comprehensive impact assessment was also carried out.
To do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria but also socio-economic criteria.

Therefore, I call on the Commission to re-examine this important aspect with the necessary time, separate from the overall package of the CAP reform, and above all, after the presentation of the necessary documents and a careful analysis of the impacts, to reconsider the criteria.

I indeed believe that we must work on identifying more swiftly, in cooperation with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities, which individuals who have come to Greece might potentially be eligible.

can also be relocated to other countries within the European Union, because firstly, they will definitely never be able to return to their home country again, and secondly, they may also possess potential and qualifications that can be beneficial and meaningful for all involved.
In essence, it is also about helping the Greeks to enable registration and identification more quickly, thereby facilitating faster aid processes.
to repatriate those who have neither the qualifications nor the right to remain in Greece or the European Union, as they would actually have the opportunity to stay in their own home countries.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Ms. Commissioner. My thanks also go to the rapporteur for her consistently very committed and exemplary work.
Much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, I can share, support this, or have partly supported it.
but then there comes a point where one must also take responsibility.
And for the EPP or for myself, I therefore claim that we must now deal with realities and cannot retreat into ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact remains that the United States has been collecting these PNR (Passenger Name Record) data for ten years now, and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact remains that none of us wish to halt data traffic entirely, even with a restrictive attitude; we want to be able to stop specific data traffic.
They had just carried that out.
The fact remains that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a halt.
And it is also a fact that the U.S. has a right to know who is entering their country.
And in my opinion, it is also a fact that the legal services have all verbally expressed to us that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
Therefore, one must also take responsibility here.
and for this we were also elected
Responsibility for citizens who would otherwise be left alone, with less protection and fewer rights.
Responsibility for the airlines, which would otherwise, and this had been explained by the Commissioner, be left in a state of absolute legal uncertainty.
Responsibility also for the EU as a contractual partner in matters of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, all things considered, and acknowledging that this agreement is not perfect, we are in favor of approving it due to its consequential benefits.
And if one wishes to better protect citizens and also provide them with improved data protection, one assumes this responsibility here as well and agrees to this agreement. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Commissioner. These were insightful remarks that you have shared with us.
Sincere thanks for that.

Numbers often speak louder than words, and to date, as you also mentioned, the European Parliament and the European Patent Office have granted almost 2000 patents on plants and nearly 1200 patents on animals, which were developed with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I may mention two outstanding examples. The approval of patents on genetically modified and breed-modified barley applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Affected are our farmers just as much as our brewers, producers as well as we, the consumers.
And this example, in my opinion, demonstrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example, the so-called long-life tomato. Not to be confused with your long-life oil that you use in your diesel engines.
With this trick by the applicant US corporation Arcadia, this patent was obtained in violation of valid EU rules.
It is not the tomato that has been patented, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This reveals the tricks being employed here. And this is despite the fact that, as you stated, Commissioner, it is clearly laid out in Article 4 of the 1998 Biopatents Directive (CLIP) that plant varieties and animal breeds, as well as essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals, are not patentable.
We are of the opinion that this definition needs to be clarified, it must be interpreted more precisely.
Technical methods employed to support conventional breeding must not result in patentability as a whole.
We specifically say no patents on life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against the patenting of life across Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we are calling for a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear stance on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive. No patents on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we call for a clear enshrining of the breeder and farmer privilege across all legislation. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Madam Chair. I would like to address the discharge of Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol. There is little to nothing to criticize.

The annual financial statement accurately reflects the financial position in 2010 in all material aspects, and all underlying transactions were conducted in compliance with regulations and are therefore lawful.
Notable are only the high transfers in relation to the overall actually low incurred costs.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters. This is, of course, understandable.
But Europol undertakes to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol intends to commit to monitoring the implementation of the budget on a monthly basis starting in 2012.
I recommend that we monitor this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend discharging Europol.
Regarding Eurojust. Here, the annual financial statement also reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all essential aspects.
All transactions here are also legal and in accordance with regulations.
But even here, high operating expenses were carried over into the year 2011.
According to Eurojust's explanation, this was primarily due to an organizational restructuring project, a new computer infrastructure, and costs related to data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better compliance with tender requirements.
I also recommend that we review this in the future and, above all, check whether all open positions are actually filled in the future.
This has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we may have to consider cutting funds, which would be detrimental to Orius.
I still recommend relief. Thank you.
Madam President, highly esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what should alarm and panic us is not merely the sheer number of unemployed youth in Europe, but the trend.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of unemployed youth increased by 26.5 percent. This is noted by the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires action. For we are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the labor market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we instill in young people a sense of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that they are turning away from this EU, as they lack reasonable prospects for work and life.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are taken. I already see some progress, but please ensure that the long-standing intellectual stagnation does not now turn into operational chaos.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program whereby young people applying abroad are now also to be financially supported, we are merely creating a traveling circus that does not address the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive. Technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then poached by richer states that are not in crisis.
What is needed now, in this crisis, is the cause of this development. Offensive measures, namely the dismantling of this austerity policy, which is holding back the economy in Europe,
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investments in education, research, and alternative energies.
that would be the way
By combining it with European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that provides young people with a perspective for life.
Final remark. This youth unemployment is also incompatible with the absurd idea of raising the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
That's why I'm urgently requesting this. Thank you.
Colleague, you just stated that everything speaking in favor of a financial transaction tax is speculation, yet you yourself provided highly speculative examples.

I would like to know from you, in light of what you have said, what your opinion is of these investigations by the Commission and the Study Commission, which very clearly state that up until now, the real economy, in its dependency, has been inadvertently included far too little.

the financial markets, that thus 95% of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money, and that one can indeed turn the negative growth effect, previously discussed, into a positive one by allocating corresponding growth-promoting public investments.
Is this for you merely speculation, or would you say that such a comprehensive, wide-ranging study by the Commission is also justified and constitutes a strong argument?

Thank you very much. Yes, colleagues, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She at least takes up the idea of involving the financial markets, taxing them, and above all, making them contribute to the costs of the crisis.
I believe this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
This is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There were a whole series of actions, petitions, and written initiatives to politicians in a number of member countries, urging the introduction of a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe that Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that is emerging here for this report, for this tax.
Certainly, this is not sufficient to stabilize and restrict the financial markets as might be necessary. But I believe that an extremely important step has been taken here.
And I would expressly like to appeal to the Council to take the voices of the citizens, both male and female, the voters, seriously and to advocate for them.
that there is a genuine introduction, that the introduction of this tax is not blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility within the

It is now in the hands of the Council to take action here. And I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, I believe that amidst all the detailed issues, which we can and will continue to discuss during the legislative process, we should not lose sight of one thing:
Be clear about this: Financial markets cannot operate on a model where banks reap the profits when things go well and taxpayers are left holding the bag when something goes wrong.
And that is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least within the eurozone, we will not experience disruptions but will instead permanently contribute to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for: ensuring that companies pay.

Having access to capital in a way that allows savers to put something aside or to save for their old age, and that thus enables financial markets to fulfill the task they were once created for: to generate added value for the real economy.
All of the factors that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy.

And therefore, it makes sense to contribute, through taxation, to ensuring that this is heavily penalized, that it is sanctioned, that it is regulated, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its purpose.
And that is why I am advocating today, with a large majority, to support this proposal.
The reform of the general system of preferences was indeed necessary.
It is now beneficial that there are longer terms and that there is increased security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has also stated.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to the World Bank classification.
In the past, the Parliament has repeatedly engaged in a very critical examination of gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with a gross national product of $4,000 or up to $12,000.
This is thus an enormous and far too wide a range. And it in no way reflects the realities on the ground.
We certainly do not find it concerning that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are excluded.
The reform in this respect was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China are, on the other hand, countries with upper-middle incomes. We certainly do not need to worry about their graduation from the APS either.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer nations, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Until now, the Commission has also at least taken into account the vulnerability criterion. That is, countries that export little or only a very limited range of goods.
This at least helps to prevent countries that are less dependent on the export of a few products and are thus very vulnerable from being overrated.
Why then did the Commission delete this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji Islands, Gabon, and Botswana will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall under the vulnerability criterion.
Why did the Commission not continue using the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission aims to coerce poorer countries into accepting less favorable free trade agreements.

The preference system, however, is an instrument to promote development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region would then play no role whatsoever.
Fortunately, however, there will still be an opportunity for colleagues in the plenary to support our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also leads to the disruption of trade regions.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
And the Commission should consider development regions more strongly instead of individual countries.
Here, too, the Greens have tabled an amendment which, hopefully, will receive widespread support.
It is also problematic when countries that only yesterday benefited from the APS are suddenly to be excluded from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and we see in our own countries that a few months are not enough for economic development.

Ultimately, we representatives must also consider whether we want to rely solely on speed in all legislative initiatives and then work with hasty compromises, or whether we would prefer to involve the entire plenary.

I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, and for democracy as well. What matters is not time or speed, but rather it takes time to uphold democracy and to properly pass laws. Thank you.

Many thanks, Mr. President, High Representative. I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observer mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to witness firsthand the hope and anticipation for a better future that the people stood in line with at the polling stations, waiting to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not fulfilled.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as colleague Nedeljewa also did in her report.
The previous president, Yusuf Kabila, has declared himself the election winner. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government forces and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it remains unclear whether third states like Rwanda are involved.
The victims in every case are the civilian population, who have been unable to live in peace and tranquility for decades now.
The wealth of the country is squandered in a quagmire of corruption. The Congo remains near the bottom in all international assessments.

The international community, here in particular the European Union with its capabilities, must increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow genuine democracy in his country. He will have the opportunity to do so in the upcoming regional elections.

to ensure that the Congolese army does not also harass the civilian population, but finally apprehends internationally sought criminals against humanity, such as Bosko and Ndanganga, and brings them to justice.
