Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Colleagues, the Tupac aims to establish additional intervention rights against crisis-ridden countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policies, is to be given more teeth.
According to the Commission's intent, member states should be able to be compelled to accept financial aid.
With the Six-Pack, extensive sanctioning measures have already been established that can be imposed on Eurozone states facing financial difficulties.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a meaningful economic policy coordination tool.
At the same time, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with expulsion from the eurozone should they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why don't we stop these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Eurozone crisis has once again dramatically intensified, as we see in Spain and Cyprus, it does not help us to put member states that are in crisis on the pillory.
We should finally develop solutions. The TUPEX reporters have certainly developed meaningful approaches to this end.
Certainly, Elisa Ferreira's suggestion of a redemption fund is noteworthy. This would be a worthwhile and meaningful measure to combat debt.
but also Jean-Paul Gauzet's proposal for an orderly state insolvency.
Central, however, is that Europe undertakes a joint and solidaristic effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being self-satisfied and pointing the finger at their partner countries.
They must start doing their homework, invest in growth, and take on their responsibilities.
Unilateral austerity policies à la Merkel have simply failed as a crisis solution.

Thank you, Mr. Chair, esteemed Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the EU heads of government finally recognized that the European Community needs a more coordinated financial and economic policy.
On the summit, they essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that members of an economic and monetary union must not only focus on how their policies affect businesses, employees, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
A single market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents member states with a strong temptation to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can economically, but also politically, bring the currency union to the point of collapse.
And the EU currently finds itself in precisely such a situation.

The German economy has undercut its neighbors for years, providing no stimulus through investments and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has driven the Eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
Therefore, it is encouraging that the Commission is gradually addressing this core issue of the euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and providing appropriate suggestions.

Quite rightly, the Federal Republic is being called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare. And quite rightly, the Commission is being asked to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a late but important realization.
And I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will strongly advocate this demand to the German government, even though there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. Commissioner, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, colleagues. First of all, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, especially Mr. Commissioner Barnier. The reason being quite straightforward: the experience from the last legislative period, prior to 2009,

was that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal for the European Private Company came up, Mr Barnier's predecessor, Mr McCreevy, allowed company law to sleep deeply. And we did not address this important issue, which is also relevant for the internal market, for five years.
have made progress.
Thank God, that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there are a plethora of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been developed to address the issue of further developing company law. We now have a very recent consultation with which, as Parliament, we of course also engage.

The Legal Affairs Committee has decided that we do not wish to do this in the form of a report. The reason being that a report would require additional time and, of course, is typically more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make our position as Parliament clear, in a subsequent resolution, on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary, much like we had done previously about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European company law. This is for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European company law. Actual gaps that essentially result in the internal market not being achieved.
I wish to cite the example of the absence of the 14th Directive on the transfer of headquarters. Most have done so following a very typical case of such a gap.
The Parliament has twice called for concrete proposals from the European Commission on this matter in its legislative reports.
There is also the expert panel, convened by the European Commission itself, which likewise held the same view on this matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms of the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered seat as well.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's previous statement on the 14th Directive falls significantly short of the Parliament's expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are optimistic that, as work progresses and if the action plan is adopted, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan after all.
Another important aspect of company law is the question of its further development with the aim of reducing burdens on companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the topic of competition.
But I believe that beyond this, there is also more to be done and further aspects that will now be clarified in the context of the consultation.
Here we likewise expect further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of the European private company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If there are individual member states, and I may express my own opinion here, if there are individual member states within the EU that are unable to break the deadlock on their own due to a lack of decisive action,

To advance Europe, one must also consider, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
And I would ask the Commission to give this matter some further thought.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, essentially a kind of Rome Regulation for cross-border matters in company law.
I also believe that this question requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
This is closely related.
insolvency law, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is an enormous amount to be done in company law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here and that it is evident that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
The parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
The details, of course, will be discussed further. We will certainly do that.
But therefore thanks to the Commission.
And now we would, of course, be delighted if the Commission were to actually take up our initiatives and convert them into concrete proposals. Thank you.
Dear Commissioner, I highly value your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But on the issue of the minimum wage, you caved to Mrs. Merkel. And regarding the question of job creation in the healthcare sector, I don't believe you.
How, please, is new work to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How is employment in the health sector supposed to be created when the Commission, in its new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, is compelling some member states to further reduce their health expenditures?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement politics, not a genuine initiative for new work.
On the contrary, due to austerity measures, there is already a shortage of remedies and medications not only in Greece.

I believe that those who continually roll out new bailout packages for banks must now advocate for a bailout package for the people, especially to secure medical care in the crisis-hit countries. Thank you.
Yes, thank you. The mood among countless pro-Europeans like me is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is at least encouraging that what we are dealing with is now being stated much more clearly, and that Italy's role is also not being overlooked.
You yourself know that you are caught in a series of traps, not just those of debt and growth, but also the trap of trust and the power trap. Estimated Commission and also addressed to the Council.
Unfortunately, you have so far failed to address the central question of decoupling finance from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here, according to expert opinion, is continually being re-evaluated, and no serious limits have been set on the shadow banking system.
Moreover, we are still faced with systemic risks. The issue of "Too Big to Fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little need to mention the rating agencies.
I can only urge and advise you, as you work towards the Council summit, to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the issue of power between the real and financial economies.
In a nutshell, they must finally demonstrate credibility to Europeans by working towards reining in the banks and ensuring that citizens are not always left to bear the burdens.
Colleague Fehrmann, you come from a country that rejected the euro, primarily because it wished to retain the flexibility of devaluation, particularly for the purpose of social policy instruments.

In light of the experiences you have now gained in Sweden, would you advise the Greeks to also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively employ this socio-political instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Yes, many thanks, Mr. President. I would also like to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a comfortable majority, with 62 votes in favor, no votes against, and no abstentions.
This demonstrates that we are actually standing very, very close together in these matters, including when it comes to compromises.

And the highest priority in these legislative procedures must, of course, be a high level of protection, a high degree of consumer protection, especially for the youngest members of our society, for vulnerable children.
As for gluten intolerance, this is a problem. Especially in kindergarten as well.
When one looks around, I have two children of this age, at the allergies and intolerances that prevail there, I believe we were right to take this approach.
And we should then also discuss this in the second reading, with the Council, with the Commission.
And I believe that we will then also achieve a good result.

Heartfelt thanks. A report about a traffic accident over the weekend, involving a truck driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into the roadside ditch, once again confirmed for me how necessary it is...
a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control by means of a digital tachograph is essential for us, for road safety, but also for the drivers themselves.
The digital roof graph represents a certain innovation. It presents new challenges, but also old problems.
The new challenges arise from new possibilities of manipulation that we must also master technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the control or lack of control in various member states.

What we are now redefining must, in my view, take several key factors into account. Firstly, it is essential to understand that not every instance of an unrecorded journey automatically triggers a rest period.
for many drivers have to load and unload, and this, of course, must also be considered working time.
The second problem is that the records of speed were removed from the file.
I consider that to be incorrect, for there are also great dangers of accidents here.
We would also like to have weight sensors, and we would also like to have a hotline for reporting fraud, which is anonymous and can be tracked.
What I will also introduce is a motion to include animal transport inspections in this regulation.
I consider this important because it, too, is a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have permanent disabilities if professional medical assistance had been provided quickly enough, that is, within the first so-called golden hour, following their accident.
We would be a significant step closer to the Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system we are discussing today cannot prevent accidents. It also does not relieve the first aider of their duty.
It solely serves, in the event of a severe accident, to automatically notify an emergency call center.
This is necessary, also to prevent abuse and overload due to minor accidents, in order to establish linguistic contact with the accident vehicle.

Only once the emergency call has been confirmed, or no one responds anymore, are emergency physicians equipped with few but life-deciding pieces of information dispatched to the scene of the accident.
Responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors integrated into the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains dormant, transmitting no signals or data and thus cannot be located.
It is thus also vastly superior to a mobile phone from a data protection perspective.
Only with the automatic, sensor-controlled awakening or the conscious manual activation does the system become active.
It then sends a pre-agreed minimum dataset of information to an emergency control center.
Across Europe, uniform standards and specifications will ensure that these data are recognized, assessed, and handled as emergency calls upon arrival.
Therefore, member states must also accordingly upgrade and expand their emergency medical service chains.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU's unified emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to work everywhere in the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable technology, a neutral, open system architecture.
Through these, other intelligent public transport services can also be offered later, such as real-time traffic information or the availability of parking spaces.

In recognition of the outstanding achievements of the automotive industry in providing private emergency call systems, they should retain their justification for existence alongside the public 112 eCall.
Users can also opt for such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may be accompanied by costs, if applicable.
use of data for workshops, insurers, towing services, or other service providers
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem that we have created today.

For if this brewery or the beverage retailer is 107 kilometers from my place of residence, I no longer have a chance that he will continue to offer me his goods in the future without having to buy a new tachograph, without there being new bureaucracy.

And therefore, dear colleagues, I have voted against this resolution today. I believe that we should not place too much of a burden on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many positive points that we were able to include, thankfully.
It was indeed planned to only accept 50 kilometers within the radius of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd of the EU Commission.
Covering around 100 kilometers, just about manageable, yes.
But what if it goes beyond that?
I think that's excessive.
And one final aspect as a representative of a labor organization in the CSU, I would also say. With this regulation, we are creating complete control of employees.
Why?
For instance, the person who offers their goods for construction or beverages, for breweries, is completely monitored throughout the entire workday via GPS.
I therefore consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, also from a data protection perspective, and would like to emphasize once again why I voted against it.
Yes, many thanks for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision,

I awaited the consent of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still raising the necessary questions regarding legal certainty with respect to ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
They did not want that. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used for delay. That is clear.
Why I said that with the wide margin for interpretation,
Because, as you have asked two questions, I must unfortunately answer both.
because one can indeed read into and interpret from these broad formulations the surveillance of the internet, auxiliary police, ISPs, and everything else.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty also does not help our economy, dear colleagues.
Mr. Leichtfried, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
or are they completely opposed to the rejection of any intellectual property.
And how do you envision the e-commerce directive being adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject a debate on these matters altogether and do not support intellectual property.
Is that correct, or how do I understand it?
Yes, many thanks. This is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but about the fundamental question of how we stand on democracy and on civil liberties.

And if we examine the agreement, we find that it stands symbolically for a lack of transparency, for the absence of democracy, and for violations of fundamental rights, as it was negotiated in secret.
and was undemocratic in a way, because the free use of the internet might no longer be possible afterward, and neither would the freedom to use generic drugs to the same extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people took to the streets and effectively voted against ACTA long ago.
Yes, a vote has been taken on ACTA, on the streets, on the internet, with regard to the Petitions Committee, in many countries, not only within the EU but also in the EU.
also outside the EU. And I believe we must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only advise you to close the file, that would be the proper thing to do.

Madam President-in-Office, as rapporteur for the Budget Committee and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency. The Financial Regulation, which provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation had been pending in the Council, and you have brought this process to a conclusion based on the results achieved under the Polish Presidency.
I would like to thank you, therefore, for two truly highly committed financial officials who have processed these dossiers and also approached the ambassadors.
They will be missed, his efficiency as a negotiator will be missed by us.
They have truly served the financial interests of the European Union.
Sincere thanks.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here now as a representative of my group and would like to support the motion put forward by my colleague, Mr. Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This necessitates a careful approach to the topic of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission, in order to clarify still outstanding questions, has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an advisory opinion.
I believe it is only respectful to the highest court of the European Union that we await this decision.
There is absolutely no substantive reason to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and opinion.
But the decision that is then made takes place in a different consciousness, in a different understanding than today.
I do not believe that those who travel the wrong way on the internet highway should dictate our policies. Hence, my request to support this motion. Thank you.
As always when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very insightful, and one wishes that what he says would have much more influence on European politics.
I intended to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a sensible approach, but only if they are oriented towards sustainability and if political frameworks are also established for this purpose.
We run the risk of using guarantees to secure risks that we may not be able to politically control.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany requires a 3,800-kilometer transmission network, but so far only 100 kilometers of these high-voltage power lines have been constructed. This is due, in part, to resistance from citizens, interestingly, those who are very environmentally conscious.
We need to come up with something from the political realm.

One idea would be for us to create shared TEN corridors, combining not only high-speed rail tracks and broadband networks, but also, potentially above and alongside the highways, constructing corresponding utility networks.
This, however, requires a much more comprehensive planning effort than has been foreseen thus far, but I would like to at least suggest this at this point.

Dear colleagues, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements within the European Union. However, I am also aware that, conversely, the borders of a country are always a highly sensitive issue for our member states and will always remain so.
I am aware that the issues between member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there exist various problems.
And by ignoring, one does not make the problems better, nor does one solve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and no one in our area would consider wanting to close the border again just because we are facing problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restriction and reprimand.
The use of random identity checks has been established because we aim to ensure security while maintaining freedom of movement.
And when we conduct our dragnet operations successfully, particularly at the borders with the Czech Republic, where not just one or two, but many drug dealers are active in numerous cases,

If they are trying to create a transition, I think it is a good idea for the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech counterpart to come together to jointly solve the problems that exist at the border.
The Commission should not regulate in this area but rather positively influence it in a supportive and corresponding manner.

We aim to put the populists in their place but to solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to seek a solution together with the Parliament so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen files, ensuring that we have freedom of movement and simultaneously guarantee the security of citizens.
Thank you. The instances of disproportionate border controls listed by the Parliament in its question also illustrate why the Council essentially wants to keep the Parliament out of Schengen matters.
The Council, in fact, continues to undermine freedom of movement without involving Parliament or any form of parliamentary oversight, and without any public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that you prefer to pat each other on the back in backrooms, away from uncomfortable questions.
No wonder the German government wants to completely rule out an evaluation of internal borders without assessment, and thus doesn't want to examine how much freedom of movement is restricted.
Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and thus also belongs in the European Parliament. Thank you.

Dear Mr. President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofias, it is a special moment for me and my political group today to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person stands at the helm of the EU whom we count among our political family.
You are assuming the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges. And it is crucial to set the course for whether the European
whether the European Union will actually have a future or whether, and this would be a historic defeat in my view, it will turn out to be a mere footnote in history.

After the conversations we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairpersons of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that you are preparing for this.
You have prepared excellently for the presidency and that you are also aware of the full extent of your task.
But, and you made this clear here today as well, you consciously want to draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of the people.
And I can tell you here, after all I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union is doing exactly that, announcing it and stating this tone.
For a long time, I have missed hearing in official speeches that this is about the people, about those who are not responsible for us being in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It will be challenging to implement this precise approach.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and I am very confident that you will do this, if above all you encourage people with your presidency and the way you express it.
advocate for their rights and ensure that the Council and European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We repeatedly discuss the euro and its stability, the necessity of which I also recognize, as it is important for the functioning of the European Union and the eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
For this, there were political conditions that were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to accept, for the functioning of the euro, that people in the European Union must go hungry, that healthcare systems collapse, or that local administrations have to cease their work.
Something has become twisted here.
It is not what we can refer to as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that the focus should be on social cohesion and solidarity, both between the individual member states and among the various population groups.
And the European Union must not continually allow itself to be used as an instrument or spokesperson for a small, specific segment of the population, nor should it present itself in this way.

And one final point I would also like to address, of course, to emphasize that all of the priorities you have mentioned are important to us, and that we will support the points that align with these priorities, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I believe that some decisions made in recent weeks and months, particularly during the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also shaped by fear.
And if the leaders of the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free choices, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of luck with your work!
Colleagues, I believe we have a very important responsibility here, especially as co-rapporteurs working together.
It will be of utmost importance for the colleague to work diligently and reliably on this dossier in the coming weeks and months.

In this regard, all eyes are currently on us and on the Council to take this step and overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step towards Europeanization, namely through a European Banking Union.
It should be noted that Parliament, with a broad majority, demanded this two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been truly necessary.
Further billions in charges have arisen as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wishes to further deepen this step for the eurozone.
And it is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so quickly.
However, the Council's decision to make the ECB the supervisor of the euro zone is associated with certain difficulties.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity and it means that in this dossier, the Parliament is not involved in the co-decision process.
Based on the experiences with the supervision package, this is not acceptable.

And therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal for changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, and thereby in fact establish the principle of the Parliament's democratic involvement.
Democratically, there are further challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If she now assumes responsibility for banking supervision, the Parliament must have full budget rights, full oversight rights, the right to ask questions, and appointment rights. I am confident that the Parliament will secure these rights with a large majority.

The complex issues regarding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility, these are what we will have to discuss thoroughly in the coming weeks. Thank you.
Thank you. With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to force these countries into free trade agreements.

These agreements are not genuine partnerships, as the term "economic partnerships" might suggest, but rather solely serve the interests of the EU and not the development interests of the partner countries.
This completely runs counter to the EU's objective of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with this goal.
Countries such as Cameroon, the Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely impacted by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as those in southeastern Africa, would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would come to an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and merely expect other countries to kindly purchase our goods.
If the Commission truly believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Development Committee of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
And we should join in this resolution in plenary session.
Many thanks. There are enormous problems in the field of human rights in Central America, as well as in Peru and Colombia.
And we, as EU parliamentarians, cannot simply turn a blind eye to this.
We will thoroughly examine the human rights roadmap requested by the European Parliament (EP) in the case of Colombia and Peru, once it has been drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of perpetrators and the safe return of displaced persons to their land.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens believe it is right that the Committee on International Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the regulatory proposal for the safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must then also confirm these points, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
The EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.
And that is why we Greens also demand, prior to any negotiation, a proper impact assessment that examines not only the economic consequences for the EU but also the impact on human rights.
Yes, thank you. Mr. Barroso, I had already made clear in the first round what I wanted to emphasize.

My concern is with the expectation of my faction that the Commission will fulfill its responsibility within the relevant bodies such as the Troika, in order to make it clear and unambiguous that we, as a parliament, demand that...
As European institutions, they ensure that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not reduced, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
This is their task.

And if we succeed in making this clear, then we also send a signal to the people who are protesting in their thousands, hundreds of thousands, in these very days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we as a faction also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
This morning, I heard the news that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we come to that people in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help or support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here we must finally take action.
And I will say one more thing: an approach held by many in positions of responsibility is that the people in Greece and other states have lived beyond their means.
You must be punished for that today and endure sanctions.
is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not attributing this to you, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is also prevalent in many countries and, unfortunately, keeps recurring in my approach as well.
Mr. Chairman, I admit I was mistaken.
I would like to make no statement on this report, but rather on the Morera report on the Agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to ask you to call me again.

Thank you very much, Madam President. The new directive establishes a framework for handling books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are copyright-protected but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rightful owner can be located should also be made available to the public.
And thus, a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Cultural Committee, it was of particular importance to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the cultural heritage of the European Union in this legislative initiative.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting institutions, there are countless unused works, and solely because their rightful owner is unknown, they have thus far not been made accessible.
This changes with the directive,
In the future, it will enable the use of this cultural asset, provided that a careful search is also carried out prior to its publication.
This is a very important point to ensure that it is not casually stated that we cannot find the right holder.
For a balance had to be found between the real, existing rights of the creators of works and the need of the public, too, to be able to use such works where the rights situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where rights holders cannot be located, the draft enables the use of the digitization of orphaned works.

Projects such as Europeana and other major European digitalization projects, as well as our museums, archives, and educational institutions, and public broadcasting, will sort through (or: organize) the material.
In the future, it must also be about opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers and also making them accessible to the public.
This draft guideline and the compromise that has now been reached, in my view, truly represent a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
And I believe that the cultural treasure, which was too small for Hing, holds immense potential.
We should continue to work on this when we revise the directive in two years' time. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. Chair, esteemed Commissioner, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council. I would be pleased if we could also find clear language in the 2013 proposal.
Signals from the Council would show how we in Europe can enhance our growth and competitiveness potential and, above all, how we can re-employ young people.
Could you please inform us which budget lines you intend to use here to promote youth employment and to prioritize entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs program or the Media Pluralism program. In these cases, there are only cuts.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by making cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is to be encouraged by the Council.
Where can this be found in the household budget presented by the Council?
Nordsee-Werken-Emmen had to file for insolvency last Wednesday as a guarantee from the Lower Saxon state government was unexpectedly not renewed.
This company, with 700 qualified jobs, is undergoing a transformation process from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a mass loan and that jobs can also be preserved. Because the 700 colleagues at SIAC and the Nordseewerke have already had to accept significant wage cuts.

Therefore, I kindly request the Commission to examine this process with due consideration and promptness, to ensure that these 700 jobs are not put at risk. These 700 jobs are essential for organizing the energy transition and for developing future-proof energy sources in the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues there suffer due to the state government's poor crisis management.
Environmental goods often appear harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes, enabling them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Networks that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in their suppression of the green protest wave.
Protesters were mass-arrested, detained, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example among many.
To add to this, the Commission, with its catalog of measures for an innovative and competitive security industry, as it is called, is promoting these questionable dual-use goods.
The aim is to achieve better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
Therefore, I would like to ask you to approve our amendments, those of the Social Democrats, and all others.
Yes, I would like to ask Ms. Regner, what do you think trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment, for example in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will not be enough.
What active role could the internal market play here?
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I believe that with today's debate on MiFID, we are addressing the core area of financial market regulation.
In this legislative period, we have made progress, as it is about regulating financial markets and not just considering individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few keywords.
We didn't exactly make our work together easy last year.

We held a hearing in committee, we conducted a consultation with all stakeholders, all interested groups, and on that basis, we developed a result with various processes, working documents, and the like, which we will present to the plenary for voting today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one, market structure.

We must, of course, acknowledge that significant developments have taken place in financial markets over recent years. Our interest, as a parliament, is to ensure that every trade in financial securities is conducted within the MiFID framework. This is why we are, under many conditions, in favor of a new category.

have agreed to so-called Organized Trading Facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, in accordance with execution in terms of execution and transaction and customer interaction, a corresponding execution at the discretion of the firm can take place.
I believe that this will make a significant contribution to ensuring that the entire market for OTC papers that are traded will be conducted within the MiFID framework.
Another major topic that was not yet considered in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.
Here, too, our focus was on establishing clear rules, ensuring that this area, which can be highly dangerous and manipulatively employed, is subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods.

Trading interruption mechanisms, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the ability for supervisory structures to review algorithms, through the introduction of a so-called tick-size regime, a minimum price increment, and corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of commodity futures markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here when it comes to limiting the speculative element in true futures markets so that we do not contribute, through flawed regulations, to a situation where people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford to buy food.
We therefore adopted a two-pronged approach, aiming to curb speculation while avoiding harm to the real economy.
We aim to achieve this with position limits, strict caps on the number of contracts or positions.
We also want to ensure, for those who can prove that they genuinely require a product, that they do not suddenly intervene in this market speculatively, using a so-called position check system.
Another topic that occupies us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would like to point out here that we have taken a very broad approach in ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The focus here is on identifying the needs of specific customer segments.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex securities.

It is about defining relevant products for target groups, conducting product tests, recording telephone conversations, providing appropriate consultations, and fulfilling disclosure obligations. However, and I would like to briefly mention this, it also involves applying the principle of subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member states should have the possibility, in accordance with their structures, to make appropriate adjustments.
I believe we are in the right area.
Once my time is up, I would like to thank everyone who contributed to this.
I find it regrettable that one only gets four minutes of speaking time for such a complex dossier.
I would like to express my gratitude to all the colleagues who have contributed to this, and to the committee for their highly constructive role over the past few weeks and months.
And I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to conclude this important file as soon as possible. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, first of all, many thanks for the generally good cooperation on this report.
We have a Commission proposal at key points, which has already made significant strides in the right direction, that we can further improve.
In the realm of market structures, there will be increased transparency, particularly in the area of derivatives trading, where comprehensive transparency will be achieved.

within the framework of MiFID. The decisions in the area of high-frequency trading, our compromise, go far beyond what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have sparked significant public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

in the area of commodity and food speculation, after great and difficult debates, which must also be said, is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now being enshrined as binding.
We still need further changes in this area, however, in order to close remaining gaps.
And I also hope for additions through the plenary vote and ultimately then in the trilogue.
And it is pleasing that Mr Barnier has already indicated his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
Where the report does have weaknesses, however, is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to ban products, which is a step forward, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
Even today, the distribution of financial products is not primarily guided by the interests of customers, but rather is strongly influenced by which products offer the highest commissions.
In Germany, and across the EU, consumers have lost significant amounts of money.
Think of the open real estate funds.
For citizens in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be performance-based orientation.
Referring to subsidiarity here is a bit simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, what long endures, finally ends well, I can only say.
The report on the type approval of L-category vehicles has ultimately turned out to be a good report after all.
The work took longer overall than we all thought, and especially longer than we had hoped. There were also far more pitfalls than we ultimately would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the rapporteur, Mr Vandekamp, for the truly cooperative and fruitful collaboration.
Together, we were able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend that this report be approved. Nevertheless, it could have been much improved.
And by better, my dear colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and, consequently, the safety of drivers has always been a top priority. This particularly applies to the safety of scooter and motorcycle riders.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is declining. This is not the case, however, for motorcycle accidents.
The reduction in the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on European roads, that was and still is my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This topic must be thoroughly addressed, especially in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
That this can be achieved through effective technologies of anti-lock braking systems, namely ABS, I remain convinced.
And I am equally convinced of the cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

What we have achieved, however, is that as of 2016, all new and, as of 2017, all existing motorcycle models with an engine displacement of 125cc or more must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer as a matter of course.
Motor scooters can optionally be equipped by the manufacturers with ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, it must unfortunately be acknowledged that we have not achieved any improvements over the Commission's proposal.
I had hoped for much more here. However, the Commission and the Member States have, to put it mildly, proven to be extremely sluggish.
What we have achieved, nevertheless, is that the Commission presented a report in 2019.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the Member States and is to examine the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
It will also be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
On this basis, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in scooters mandatory.
As you can see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will aim to close the binding gap in legislation starting in 2019.
I am confident that the data collected will vindicate my position.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheeled vehicle drivers in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Matthias Grote, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
and I believe that this also applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new development in energy markets driven by unconventional resources, particularly in the case of gas, but also in oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria about a grand gas future, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint large-scale horror and terror scenarios that have nothing to do with reality.

I believe that we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to transform all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and consumers, and that the economic calculations of traditional energy sources are also being called into question.
in the development we should face up to ourselves

I believe that we should acknowledge that this could also present an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare to harness and utilize new technologies positively, to fairly assess opportunities and risks, and to avoid falling into ideological debates. Thank you.
Commissioner, thank you for your response. It does not entirely satisfy me.
for I consider it a very, very long period of time, a year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only receiving a response so late.
I believe that a complainant who goes to the trouble, and usually they have already exhausted the entire legal process in their member state, deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this form, we should treat them accordingly.

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates rights. This is now a declaration of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point. I have no objection, if it serves the purpose, to attempting to reach a kind of consensual clarification with the member state.
Only, that will not always be sufficient.
We observe, for instance, that proceedings are relatively swift in economic matters when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a very, very large number of citizens demand action from the European Union, or also social rights, then progress is made somewhat more slowly.
I believe that these facts, too, must be taken into account explicitly.

And I hope that for the next report, we will have, as it were, a clear formalization of the rights of the complainant vis-à-vis the Commission, which are indeed clear and which are also communicated effectively.
Once again, if we truly want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so many procedures here in the European Parliament and in the Council,
We have jointly decided on this. We must then inform those who are responsible, those who are truly committed to a European approach, as thoroughly and precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great, great importance to me.
And I will also carefully observe again next time what has developed here. Thank you.
Mr. President, colleagues, five years ago, the EU's Central Asia Strategy was launched.
When asked today about the balance sheet of this strategy, the assessment is mixed.
We observe how individual member states strive for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries of this region. On the other hand, efforts are not progressing.
Accompanying states on their path of transformation towards modern democratic societies, or as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, where even setbacks characterize development.

Nevertheless, or precisely for this reason, the European Union and its member states must more strongly express their influence in this region collectively, including and especially vis-à-vis Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU states.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only result in allowing competitors for influence in this geopolitically significant country, who do not prioritize pressing for the observance of civil and human rights, to assert their influence even more strongly than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to upholding civil rights is the central aspect of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations on a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation in this regard. Sincere thanks.
Ladies and Gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us via the Parliament's video stream, as you clearly lack both the capacity and the inclination to engage with us live.
I regard the Council's absence here and today as a grave disrespect to the Parliament.
Rather than avoiding this debate, you should reveal the secret as to why you oppose any improvement in the protection of personal data in the police and judicial sectors through a directive.

Police and justice systems have, as we know, been a hotbed of data protection violations for years. Not just in the case of SWIFT, but on a daily basis, for example, when data of citizens who demonstrate against Nazis is unlawfully collected and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors and for the police and judiciary. This is what it's about, in order to be able to guarantee civil rights.
If you, the Council, call on the Parliament to constructively contribute to data protection regulations such as the EU PNR or Europol, then this must surely also apply in reverse to the Council.
Therefore, I demand that you finally put an end to the policy of obstruction in the field of data protection.
